column1: During his collegiate career James made occasional trips to New York, always with the theater and the tavern as his objectives.
column2: Triumphantly now he feels himself actually a New Yorker, a dweller in no mean city.
column3: Joyfully, therefore, he goes forth every noon to explore the territory of his new possession.
column4: James is, let it be understood, nearer 20 than 25.
column5: He is beginning to regard his diploma with some disrespect, but he still wears his fraternity pin on an obscure corner of his waistcoat.
column6: Every Saturday morning he gets an envelope containing a $10 bill and a $5 bill, and he has already formulated in his mind an eloquent appeal which cannot fail, he believes, to increase that amount to $18.50.
column7: James endeavors to seem as sophisticated as the chauffeur of a taxicab; not for worlds would he betray the innocent delight with which he regards the city of his habitation.
column8: With James's occupation from 9 in the morning until the luncheon hour we have no concern.
column9: Perhaps he sits on a high stool and ciphers in a great ledger, perhaps he haltingly dictates letters to a patronizing stenographer, perhaps he urges certain necessities or luxuries upon a suspicious public.
column10: The important fact of his life--for us and, in a measure, for him--is that once every day he answers the welcome summons of the unknown.
column11: Luncheon is a tiresome obligation, quickly to be fulfilled.
column12: His mother would be vexed to see him gulp his malted milk or bolt his sandwich.
column13: On some occasions, with a pleasant sense of recklessness, he enters a bar, and, with something of a flourish, consumes beer and free lunch.
column14: With some difficulty he refrains from looking over the swinging doors before leaving, as he did in his home town, to make sure that none of his neighbors are coming down the street.
column15: James left his desk only six minutes ago and his luncheon is already over.
column17: Behold him tasting rapturously of every second of these minutes!
column18: Behind a cheap but decorative cigar he walks up, perhaps, Fifth Avenue, undeniably that excellent thoroughfare's possessor.
column19: For his delight is Diana poised on her tower of purple memories; the grass of Madison Square is greener than that of his father's lawn; tulips more vivid than these never bloomed in the rich gardens of Holland.
column20: He is considered a sympathetic person, but at noon, I fear, his attitude is that of a realist.
column21: For he watches with ingenuous interest the antics of that drunkard on a park bench, and regards the arrival of the patrol wagon and summary removal of the culprit as a drama got up solely for his entertainment.
column22: Regrettable as it may seem, it is with heightened spirits that he continues his stroll.
column23: Now he has reached a great bookshop which even the penniless find hospitable.
column24: "Some day," says James to himself, "two hundred copies of my novel will draw a crowd around this plate glass window."
column25: Mentally he arranges an effective window display and goes on to feast his eyes on vellum and shagreen, on calf delicately tooled and parchment gay with gold leaf and many colored inks.
column26: Sometimes he enters the shop (the clerks are indulgent to James and his kind) and, over the merry pages of _Jugend_ and _La Vie Parisienne_, rejoices that his father made him study modern languages at college.
column27: But literature must not claim too much of his fast-fleeting hour.
column28: There are shops at hand whose windows show things stranger than books; chairs and bedsteads eloquent of the genius of Adam and Heppelwhite; the massive silver platter on which old Wardle carved a Christmas goose when Mr. Pickwick was his guest; a mighty flagon that brimmed with red wine for Pantagruel; a carved jade bracelet from the brown arm of the Princess Badoura; the sword of Robert Bruce.
column29: All lands, all ages have sent their treasures to New York this noon for the entertainment of James Jones.
column30: It may be that this square of Japanese embroidery, on which fantastic knights thrust tremendous javelins at red and green dragons under astonished willows, was made in Paterson, N. J.
column32: The colors are not therefore less bright.
column33: James is not a purchaser, he is merely a spectator of the greatest raree-show in the world.
column34: It is well for him to be deceived in the splendors displayed before him.
column35: Not so many years ago he would prefer a red glass ball to the Kohinoor and a hand organ with a monkey to a piano with Paderewski.
column36: James yet retains a receptivity almost infantile; but it would pain him to be told so.
column37: They are not gregarious, at noon, these young discoverers of New York.
column38: They are selfish in their adventuring, for a vision shared is only half a vision.
column39: James, I know, is annoyed when he finds an acquaintance gobbling a sandwich at his luncheon counter or staring in a jeweler's window that he has come to regard as his own private property.
column40: On Sundays he is sociable enough; he is glad of a companion on his journeys across and up and down Manhattan, among the Italians and negroes of the upper west side, through the loud ghetto and speciously weird Chinatown, in the deliberate sylvanity of Central Park and the Bronx Gardens.
column41: In the evening, too, he is not at all a recluse.
column42: But at noon he has no appetite for conversation; he would not have his attention taken from the strange streets by an accustomed human being.
column43: James has never ridden on a London bus, yet I believe in the truth of his unspoken thought, that a Fifth Avenue bus is the most excellent vehicle in the world.
column44: The London bus depends for its charm on a number of non-essential qualities; on the humor of its driver (are the chauffeurs of London's electric buses also masters of epigram?
column45: ), on the quaintness and antiquity of the thoroughfare, on the military efficiency of the traffic policemen, on the philmayishness of the passengers.
column46: The Fifth Avenue bus has one reason for existence: it shows its passengers Fifth Avenue.
column48: So one may (if one is young enough to be so foolish and so wise) ride, like the Gaikwar of Baroda in his swaying howdah, high above the people for a golden hour.
column49: He may start at uneasy Washington Square, where ancient respectability wars with young bohemianism.
column50: Soon he looks down on the throngs of new Americans that tramp the once proud pavement.
column51: From his high seat he sees them, the small, dark men and women who, like him, are for a time released from labor.
column52: They move slowly in great crowds, they eat frugal meals, the wares of curb-side peddlers, they talk and gesture incessantly.
column53: What does James think of them?
column54: I do not believe that his opinion is worth knowing.
column55: But he enjoys, I know, the tour through the traffic-filled intersection of Broadway and Twenty-third Street, and he is not old enough to notice with regret the gradual deterioration of the latter street.
column56: Freed from the close company of baser vehicles, how triumphantly the bus whirrs up the broad street past the square, among the splendid shops and clubs and churches--the true New Yorker, I think, names them in this order.
column57: But James must not give too much attention to the lovely Gothic lines of St. Thomas's, or the lovely Byzantine lines of that pink chiffon lady in the landau--the luncheon hour draws to a close, and punctuality, he still believes, is a business virtue.
column58: The brevity of this recess is essential to it.
column59: If the time be indefinitely increased, if the young adventurer be allowed all the morning and all the afternoon for his wandering, then all the zest goes out of the adventure.
column60: There is that trusted veteran employee in the corner of the office.
column61: He receives fabulous sums on pay day and may go out to luncheon whenever he desires, with no time clerk to censor him.
column62: He knows New York less than does James.
column63: But does his curiosity urge him forth to long adventures?
column64: Over his stale morning's paper in the deserted office, seated before his familiar task, he eats his sordid and wife-made luncheon!
column65: But the noon adventurer is not limited to Fifth Avenue.
column66: The antique shops of Fourth Avenue charm him with pewter and brass, they cheer his heart with sun dials from English rose gardens and crucifixes from convents of Dante's land and time.
column67: At Twenty-third Street stalls he reads bits of forgotten writings and breathes the pleasant scent of worn calfskin.
column68: Perhaps on the 15-cent rack he comes upon a prize.
column69: Here is a little book of English verse by a Japanese poet.
column72: The adventurer buys it, as the late Mr. Morgan would buy a Nuremburg Bible, and salves his economical conscience by rolling his own cigarettes for a while.
column73: There are great sights for him, now and then.
column74: People who seemed, not so long ago, as legendary as Cuchulain and Cinderella appear to him on these noon expeditions, most startlingly human and real.
column75: He sees Mr. Roosevelt leave the Charities Building to enter a waiting taxicab.
column76: He visits the bootblack and in the chair next to him sits Mr. Bliss Carman, crowned with the huge black hat that is the livery of Vagabondia.
column77: On Fourteenth Street a big black-haired man and a little spectacled woman stop to laugh at the fortune-telling paroquets.
column78: With a delicious thrill the adventurer recognizes Mr. Ben Reitman and Miss Emma Goldman.
column79: Nor are his adventures confined to seeing.
column80: There is plenty of action, sometimes.
column81: Once, as he stared into the windows of an Oriental rug shop, he was aware of a thin, hunted-looking man who demanded his attention.
column82: "I beg your pardon, Sir," said the hunted-looking man, "but can you tell me where I can find a parnbroker?"
column83: I do not know why the hunted-looking man said "parnbroker," instead of "pawnbroker," but James always tells the story this way.
column85: "The reason I wanna know is," said the hunted-looking man very rapidly, "I gotta very fine stone here.
column86: I got into a little trouble in a hotel uptown; I gotta sell it right away very cheap."
column87: And from a dirty pasteboard box he drew what seemed to be a large diamond ring.
column88: Now was the thoroughly interested James aware of yet another stranger who sought his attention, a prosperous-looking man, who smoked a fat cigar and flourished a silver-headed stick, who seemed trying to caution James against buying the diamond.
column89: James had only 35 cents in his pocket, and was not a buyer, but a spectator of jewelry anyway.
column91: Then said the prosperous-looking man to James: "Excuse me for buttin' in, old man, but I didn't want to see you stung.
column92: Sometimes these here fellers got real stones, sometimes they got fakes.
column93: Now I'm a professional jeweler and I got my microscope that I look at diamonds with in my pocket.
column94: Now, you call that guy back and tell him I'm a friend of yours and I'll examine that stone and tell you if it's any good."
column95: The hunted-looking man gave rather too dramatic a start of surprise when called back by the suspicious but curious James.
column96: "It's worth $500," he said, "but I'll sell it for $50.
column97: I got into a little trouble at a hotel uptown, and I gotta sell it cheap."
column98: Professionally, elaborately, impressively, the prosperous-looking man screwed a glass into his eye and squinted at the stone.
column99: Then, taking James several yards away from the hunted-looking man, he said: "That's a genuine stone worth easy $500 if it's worth a cent.
column100: I know a place they'll give us $500 for it this afternoon on account of me being in the trade.
column101: Now, you keep him here while I go round the corner and get $25 from my bank and then we'll buy that stone together and make $225 apiece before two hours is gone.
column104: Then--as might have been expected--the hunted-looking man offered James the diamond for $25.
column105: "You can put one over on that big-guy," he said.
column106: "Slip me $25 and we beat it before he gets back.
column107: You can clean up $450 on it.
column108: I'm afraid of that big guy; I think he's gone after a cop."
column109: Now, these two confidence men had worked hard with James.
column110: He should not have taken such delight in their discomfiture as he climbed the steps of a bus and bade them farewell.
column111: When he met the hunted-looking man and the prosperous-looking man together on Broadway a few days later they cut him, and I do blame them.
column112: But they gave him a real adventure, at any rate, an adventure not to be met by those who squander their noon hour sitting dully in sedate restaurants.
column113: Then there was the adventure of the picture gallery.
column114: James went on one occasion to a futurist exhibition in a tiny room not far from Madison Square.
column115: Galleries are not crowded at noon, but from the room that James approached came sounds not to be accounted for even by the crazy canvases on its walls.
column116: Of course James went in, and found a futurist painter wrestling with the agent of a collection agency.
column117: The combatants rose, and demanded James's name and address, that he might be summoned to court as a witness to assault and battery.
column118: But he never received either summons.
column119: Perhaps it was because he gave his name as Henry Smith of Yonkers.
column120: Episodes like these have little charm for the middle-aged or for young men prematurely aged by spending their childhood in New York.
column121: These have their compensations, no doubt; their lives are not utterly bleak.
column122: But not for them is the daily romance of the young man who has just come to the city, who enjoys the proud novelty of working for wage, to whom every noon come sweet and strange the streets' compelling voices.
column123: SIGNS AND SYMBOLS Those people whom an hostile fate has made both athletes and reformers have among their aversions one which they proclaim with an enthusiasm so intense as to be almost infectious.
column124: They dislike passionately the harmless, unnecessary sign board when it has been so placed as to become a feature of the rural landscape.
column125: Wooden cows silhouetted against the sunset only irritate them by their gentle celebrations of malted milk; the friendliest invitation to enjoy a cigarette, a corset or a digestive tablet fills them with anger if it comes from the face of a sea-shadowing cliff or from among the ancient hemlocks of a lofty mountain.
column126: There is, of course, a modicum of reason in their attitude.
column127: It is wrong to paint the lily at all; it is doubly wrong to paint "Wear Rainproof Socks" across its virgin petals.
column128: It is wrong to mar beauty; that is an axiom of all aesthetics and of all ethics.
column129: It would be wrong, for example (although it would be highly amusing), to throw by means of a magic lantern great colored phrases against Niagara's sheet of foam; it would be wrong to carve (as many earnest readers of our magazines believe has been done), an insurance company's advertisement on the Rock of Gibraltar.
column130: But the aesthete-reformer, in condemning such monstrosities as these, condemns merely an hypothesis.
column131: And since the hypothesis obviously is condemnable, he starts a crusade against the innocent facts upon which the purely hypothetical evil is based.
column132: It is wrong to mar the snowy splendor of the Alps; therefore, he says, the Jersey meadows must not bear upon their damp bosom the jubilant banner of an effective safety-razor.
column133: The sylvan fastness of our continent must be saved from the vandal; therefore, he says, you may not advertise breakfast food on a hoarding in the suburbs of Paterson.
column134: If the aesthete-reformers in question would examine the subject dispassionately they would see that there is really nothing in the sign board as it stands to-day about which they may justly complain.
column135: Advertisers do not deliberately annoy the public; they would not be so foolish as to seek to attract people by spoiling what was beautiful.
column136: It must be remembered that a landscape may be rustic and yet not beautiful.
column137: The aesthete does not dislike, instead he hails with enthusiasm, a worn stone bearing the dim inscription "18 Mil.
column139: Why then should he shudder when he sees a bright placard which shouts "18 Miles to the White Way Shoe Bazaar, Paterson's Pride"?
column140: To my mind there is a vivacity and a humanness about the second announcement utterly lacking in the first.
column141: The aesthete dotes upon the swinging boards which with crude paintings announce the presence of British inns.
column142: If "The Purple Cow, by Geoffrey Pump.
column143: Entertainment for Man and Beast" delights his soul, why does he turn in angry sorrow from "Stop at the New Mammoth Hotel when you are in Omaha--500 Rooms and Baths--$1.50 up--All Fireproof"?
column144: It is a cheerful invitation, and it should bring to jaded travelers through the track-pierced wastes a comfortable sense of approaching welcome and companionship.
column145: There are many things which might be said in favor of urban sign boards, especially in favor of those elaborate arrangements in colored lights which make advertisements of table waters and dress fabrics as alluringly lovely as the electrical splendor of the first act of Dukas' "Ariane et Barbe Bleu."
column146: But in the city the sign board is always something supererogatory; it may be decorative, but it is not necessary.
column147: One does not need a six-yard announcement of a beer's merit when there are three saloons across the street; even the placards of plays line almost uselessly the thoroughfares of a district in which the theaters are conspicuous.
column148: But in the country the sign boards are no luxuries but stern necessities.
column149: This the aesthete-reformers fail to see because they lack a sense of the unfitness of things.
column150: It is their incongruity which gives to rustic sign boards the magic of romance.
column151: The deliberately commercial announcement, firmly set in an innocent meadow or among the eternal hills, has exactly the same charm as a buttercup in a city street or a gray wood-dove fluttering among the stern eaves of an apartment house.
column152: What a benefaction to humanity these rural sign boards are!
column153: To the farmer they are (in addition to being a source of revenue) a piquant suggestion of the wise and wealthy city.
column154: He loves and fears the city, as mankind always loves and fears the unknown.
column155: Once he thought that it was paved with gold.
column156: He must have thought so, otherwise how could he have accounted for the existence of gold bricks?
column157: He is less credulous now, but still the big signs down where the track cuts across the old pasture pleasantly thrill his fancy.
column158: And what would a railway journey be without these gay and civilizing reminders?
column159: They hide the shame of black and suicidal bogs with cheery hints of vaudeville beyond, they throw before the privacy of farmhouses a decent veil of cigarette advertisements.
column160: He who speeds vacation-ward from the city is glad of them, for they remind him that he is where factories and huge shops may come only in this pictured guise, thin painted ghosts of their noisy selves.
column161: He who gladly speeds back to domesticity and the ordered comforts of metropolitan life sees them as welcoming seneschals, glorious advance-posts of civilization.
column162: They are the least commercial of all commercial things, they are as human and as delightful as explorers or valentines.
column163: THE GREAT NICKEL ADVENTURE Whenever I read Mr. Chester Firkins' excellent poem "On a Subway Express" I am filled with amazement.
column164: It is not strange that Mr. Firkins turned the subway into poetry, it is strange that the subway does not turn every one of its passengers into a poet.
column165: There are, it is true, more comfortable means of locomotion than the subway; there are conveyances less crowded, better ventilated, cooler in Summer, warmer in Winter.
column166: A little discomfort, however, is an appropriate accompaniment of adventure.
column167: And subway-riding is a splendid adventure, a radiant bit of romance set in the gray fabric of the work-a-day world.
column168: The aeroplane has been celebrated so enthusiastically in the course of its brief life that it must by now be a most offensively conceited machine.
column169: Yet an aeroplane ride, however picturesque and dangerous, has about it far less of essential romance than a ride in the subway.
column170: He who sails through the sky directs, so nearly as is possible, his course; he handles levers, steers, goes up or down, to the left or the right.
column171: Or if he is a passenger, he has, at any rate, full knowledge of what is going on around him, he sees his course before him, he can call out to the man at the helm: "Look out for that cornet's hair!
column172: Turn to the left or the point of that star will puncture our sail!"
column173: Now, unseen dangers are more thrilling than those seen; the aeroplane journey has about it inevitably something prosaic.
column174: This is the great charm of the subway, that the passengers, the guards, too, for that matter, give themselves up to adventure with a blind and beautiful recklessness.
column175: They leave the accustomed sunlight and plunge into subterranean caverns, into a region far more mysterious than the candid air, into a region which since mankind was young has been associated with death.
column176: Before an awed and admiring crowd, the circus acrobat is shut into a hollow ball and catapulted across the rings; with not even a sense of his own bravado, the subway passenger is shut into a box and shot twenty miles through the earth.
column177: Once there lived on West One Hundred and Eighty-second Street a man of uncompromising practicality, a stern rationalist.
column178: He was as advanced as anything!
column179: He believed in the materialistic interpretation of history, economic determinism, and radium; this, he said, with some pride, was his Creed.
column180: Often he expressed his loathing for "flesh-food," more frequently for "Middle Class morality," most frequently for faith.
column183: It makes me sick to see the way people have been humbugged in all ages.
column184: The capitalist class has told them something was true, something nobody could understand, and they've--blindly accepted it, the idiots!
column185: I believe in what I see--I don't take chances.
column186: I don't trust anybody but myself."
column187: Yet every day this man would give himself up to the subway with a sweet and child-like faith.
column188: As he sat in the speeding car, he could not see his way, he had no chance of directing it.
column189: He trusted that the train would keep to its route, that it would stop at Fourteenth Street and let him off.
column190: He could not keep it from taking him under the river and hurling him out into some strange Brooklyn desert.
column191: When he started for home in the evening, he read the words "Dyckman Street" on the car window with a medieval simplicity, and on the guarantee of these printed words, placed there by minions of the capitalist class, he gave up the privilege of directing his course.
column192: The train, he believed, would not at Ninety-sixth Street be switched off to a Bronx track; the sign told him that he was safe, and he believed it.
column193: So the subway caused him to exercise the virtue of faith, made him, for a time, really a human being.
column194: Perhaps it is the sharing of this faith that makes a subway crowd so democratic.
column195: Surely there is some subtly powerful influence at work, changing men and women as soon as they take their seats, or straps.
column196: For one thing, they become alike in appearance.
column197: The glare of the electric light unifies them, modifying swarthy faces and faces delicately rouged until they are nearly of one hue.
column198: Then, the differences of attitude are lost, and attitudes are great instruments of subordination.
column199: The ragged bootblack does not kneel at the broker's feet; he sits close beside him, or perhaps, comfortably at rest, watches the broker clutch a strap and struggle to keep his footing.
column200: "Tired clerks, pale girls, street-cleaners, business men, boys, priests and sailors, drunkards, students, thieves"--all gain a new sincerity.
column201: Neither the millionaire's imperiousness nor the beggar's professional humility can make the train go faster, so both are laid aside.
column202: Distinctions of race and caste grow insignificant, as in a company confronting one peril or one God.
column203: This is not theory, it is fact.
column204: The subway passenger purchases a nickel's worth of speed and he must take with it a nickel's worth of democracy.
column205: Perhaps it is the youthful romanticism of America which makes our subways so much more exciting than those of Europe.
column206: The Englishman is too cautious and too conservative to trust himself away from the earth's surface more than two minutes at a time.
column207: So the trains that run through the London tube are tame, cowardly things.
column208: They timidly run underground for half a mile or so and pop their heads out into the air and sunlight or fog at every station.
column209: But the New York subway train is ready to take a chance.
column210: It dives into the earth and "stays under," like a brave diver, for an hour at a time.
column211: And when it does emerge, what splendor attends its coming!
column212: There is a glimmer of sunshine at the One Hundred and Sixteenth Street Station; the blue and white of the walls and pillars reflect a light not wholly artificial.
column213: Then there is a brief stretch of fantastically broken darkness.
column214: Passengers in the first car can see ahead of them, at Manhattan Street, a great door of sunshine.
column215: At last there is a strange change in the rumble of the wheels, for the echoing roof and walls are gone, and the train leaves its tunnel not to run humbly over the ground, but to rise higher and higher until it comes to a sudden halt above the chimneys and tree tops.
column216: To say that the grub becomes a butterfly does not fit the case, for the grub is a slow-moving beast and a butterfly's course is capricious.
column217: Rather, it is as if, by some tremendous magic, a great snake became a soaring eagle.
column218: And how keenly all the passengers enjoy their few seconds in the open air!
column219: When they hurried down the steps to the train, they were scornful of the atmosphere they were leaving, they had no thought of tasting wind and watching sunlight.
column220: Now they are become, for the moment, connoisseurs of these delectable things; they wish the train would linger at Manhattan Street, not inevitably plunge at once into its roaring cavern.
column221: But the train is wise, it knows brevity is essential to all exquisite things, so it gives its passengers only an evanescent glimpse of the glories they have just now learned to appreciate.
column222: This is a part of the great conspiracy of the subway.
column223: It is regarded only as a swift and convenient and uncomfortable carrier, and it has no wish to be otherwise interpreted.
column224: But those who have studied it know the hidden purposes it constantly and effectively serves.
column225: It is showing our generation the value of mankind's commonest and most precious gifts, by taking them away.
column226: Now, it is good for man or beast to stand on solid ground in the sunlight, breathing clean air.
column227: Also fellowship is good, and the talk of friends.
column228: We forgot the value of these, we shut ourselves up in dark rooms and we spared no time to social exercise.
column229: Then--to punish and cure our folly--came the subway, making our journeys things close and dark in which conversation is a matter of desperate effort.
column230: And now how kind and talkative are people who go home together from the subway station after their daily disciplinary ride!
column231: They are grateful, too--although it may be subconsciously--for the familiar sights and sounds of the earth, for houses and streets and light that does not come from a wire in a bottle.
column232: They take gladly the great common things; they are simple, natural, democratic.
column233: So they spend much of their leisure out of doors, these men and women who are underground two hours every weekday.
column234: In the evenings and on Sunday afternoons, they walk the pleasant streets with eager delight.
column235: They are curious about the loveliness far beneath which they daily speed.
column236: They have learned something of the art of life.
column237: Of course, the subway has its incidental charms--its gay fresco of advertisements, for instance, and its faint mysterious thunder when it runs near the surface of the street on which we stand.
column238: But its chief service to man--perhaps its reason for existence--is that it gives him adventure.
column239: In this adventure he meets the spirit of faith and the spirit of democracy, which is an aspect of charity.
column240: And by their influence he becomes, surely though but for a time, as a little child.
column241: THE URBAN CHANTICLEER If the rooster selected tree-tops for his roosting, crowed mournfully at the moon, and were a wild, unfriendly bird, every man's hand would be against him.
column242: But we forgive him his ugliness and conceit, not only because he is a dutiful citizen of the barnyard, but also because now, as in the days of the noble Horatio, he obligingly acts as "trumpet to the morn."
column243: On account of this romantic and sometimes useful custom, he wears a sentimental halo.
column244: M. Rostand has made him the hero of a drama.
column245: When will some wise playwright celebrate his urban prototype, the alarm clock?
column246: The spirit in which this question is asked is not wholly one of mockery.
column247: For the alarm clock is close to humanity; in the city household, few bits of furniture are more personal and necessary.
column248: It is a faithful servant, this loud-voiced creature of steel and glass, obedient, punctual, patient.
column249: And its association with its owner, I had almost written its master, is so peculiarly intimate as to give it a personality and an attitude toward life.
column250: In the first place, it is irresistibly egotistic.
column251: There are some usual possessions which become subconscious things, their identities merging with the shadows of the vague land of habit.
column252: One may, for instance, possess a watch and yet not be aware of the watch as he is aware of his alarm clock.
column253: He lifts it from and returns it to his pocket; he winds it, with a gesture almost involuntary; he takes his information from his dial as thoughtlessly as he takes his breath from the atmosphere.
column254: Though it be made of fine gold, cunningly chased and blazoned with precious stones, it is to him, after the first delight of its acquisition, the unregarded means to an important end.
column255: So long as it serves him unprotestingly, he thinks of it no more than of his soul.
column256: People do not specifically ask him to consult his watch, they ask, "What time is it?"
column258: Not thus does an alarm clock sink into oblivion.
column259: At least twice in twenty-four hours its owner must be vividly aware of its existence.
column260: It imperiously demands of him conscious action.
column261: In the morning clangorously, at night dumbly, it insists on attention.
column262: He must with thought adjust its mechanism, he must give it intelligent orders.
column263: And whether he rises at its summons or instead shuts out with a pillow its voice and that of conscience, he cannot ignore it.
column264: By no effort of will could Frankenstein forget his monster.
column265: Not that the alarm clock is always a thing monstrous and threatening.
column266: It obeys orders with soldierly exactness but its sympathy is most unmartial.
column268: True, its ordinary note is something dry and monotonous.
column269: This comes from its perfect sense of the fitness of things; the call to business should be business-like.
column270: But what triumphant peals burst from its tiny belfry when it bids you rise and put on robes of honor!
column271: It can mimic the proud mirth of wedding bells; it knows the mighty song that rang from all the towers of London to cheer Dick Whittington.
column272: And that it can utter harsh and strident grief, those know who lie down with Sorrow and must awaken with her.
column273: Even the most materialistic man has for his alarm clock a shame-faced personal regard.
column274: He speaks of it deprecatingly, with a humorous show of indignation.

column383: INCONGRUOUS NEW YORK That dislike of the obvious which is the chief characteristic of American humor is clearly exemplified in the names of most of New York's streets.
column384: The dwellers in a great European city would give their proudest avenue of great shops and rich clubs some dignified and significant title, like the Rue de la Paix or the Friedrichstrasse.
column385: The Asiatics would give it a name more definitely descriptive and laudatory, like "The Street of the Thousand and One Mirrors of Delight."
column386: The New Yorkers, "laconic and Olympian," designate it by a simple numeral.
column388: It comes partly from the national reticence, this prosaic name of a poetic thoroughfare.

column412: Nobility, love, courage, beauty--the possession of these qualities does not give to a man or a woman romantic charm.

column441: IN MEMORIAM: JOHN BUNNY There was a clown named Joseph Grimaldi.

column529: THE DAY AFTER CHRISTMAS Of course, people still ride on the elevated railways.

column756: His most serious offense is not that he prefers that which is evil to that which is good, and praises untrue and inartistic work because the worst part of his nature responds to its salacious appeal.
column757: His most serious offense is that he thinks that the Hall Caines and Marie Corellis of Russia really are representative writers, and that he insults a race of great romanticists and great realists by calling works that are thoroughly morbid and vile "very Russian."

column796: ABSINTHE AT THE CHESHIRE CHEESE Belonging rather to gossip than to literary history, the following anecdote is nevertheless significant when considered merely as an illustrative legend.
column797: A certain London publisher, it is said, recently had in his possession a notebook that had been found, after his death, among the effects of Lionel Johnson.
column798: The poet had scribbled in it memoranda of all sorts: notes for essays, stray epigrams, rough drafts of poems.
column799: He had also copied into it, from books and magazines, bits of prose and verse that gave him pleasure.
column800: Well, one day this friend said to Johnson's loyal friend, Miss Louise Imogen Guiney--and, by the way, Miss Guiney is not my authority for this story--"Do you know, I have found in this notebook an unpublished poem by Lionel Johnson!
column801: It is very beautiful, far better than any of Johnson's published poems.
column803: Thereupon he opened the notebook and began to declaim:   Last night, ah, yesternight, between her lips and mine     There fell thy shadow, Cynara!
column804: Of course Lionel Johnson, like every other lover of good poetry, had felt the charm of Ernest Dowson's now famous poem which is headed by the phrase, "Non Sum Qualis Eram Bonae Sub Regno Cynarae," and had hastily copied it in his notebook, perhaps from Dowson's manuscript at some meeting of the Rhymers' Club.
column805: The point of this story is that the publisher, knowing Johnson chiefly as a celebrant of the Catholic faith, attributed to him not one of Dowson's poems about nuns, or Extreme Unction, or the Blessed Sacrament, but a lyric which at least in tradition and phrasing is obviously pagan.
column806: Out of the mouths of babes and publishers!
column807: That wise and sympathetic critic, Miss Katherine Bregy, has justly praised the lovely poetry which resulted from Ernest Dowson's return to the faith of his ancestors.
column808: She has demonstrated, for all time, the genuineness of his Catholicism, and made Mr. Victor Plarr's recent sneer at his dead friend's conversion seem the most futile thing in his entertaining but ineffective book.
column809: It would be absurd for me to attempt to add to Miss Bregy's interpretative appreciations of the "sculptural beauty" of Dowson's religious poems.
column810: But, like the simple-minded publisher previously mentioned, I find indications, if not of piety, at least of normality, sanity, wholesomeness, virtue, in nearly every poem which this so-called "decadent" wrote.
column811: There are, and there have always been since sin first came into the world, genuine "decadents."
column812: That is, there have been writers who have devoted all their energies and talents to the cause of evil, who have consistently and sincerely opposed Christian morality, and zealously endeavored to make the worse appear the better cause.
column813: But every poet who lays a lyric wreath at a heathen shrine, who sings the delights of immorality, or hashish, or suicide, or mayhem, is not a decadent: often he is merely weak-minded.
column814: The true decadent, to paraphrase a famous saying, wears his vices lightly, like a flower.
column815: He really succeeds in making vice seem picturesque and amusing and even attractive.
column816: Now, this is exactly what Ernest Dowson never could do.
column817: He was a member, it will be remembered, of that little band of "esthetic" poets which was called the Rhymers' Club.
column818: With them he spent certain evenings at the Cheshire Cheese and there he drank absinthe.
column819: This is a significant and symbolic fact.
column820: Not in some ominous Parisian cellar, but beneath the beamed ceiling of a most British inn, still stained with smoke from the pipe of Dr. Samuel Johnson, among thick mutton chops and tankards of musty ale, in a cloud of sweet-scented steam that rose from the parted crust of the magnificent pigeon-pie, Ernest Dowson drank absinthe.
column821: Of course it is true--more's the pity!--that in the melancholy years just before his death he drank absinthe in places where it is terribly fitting to drink absinthe.
column822: But this does not destroy the splendid symbolism of his act of drinking absinthe in the Cheshire Cheese.
column823: The wickedness in his poems and in his prose-sketches are always as affected and incongruous as is that pallid medicine in any honest tavern.

column1063: Gerard Hopkins' purpose--a purpose impossible of fulfillment but not therefore less worth the effort--was "to arrange words like so many separate gems to compose a whole expression of thought, in which the force of grammar and the beauty of rhythm absolutely correspond."

column1067: PHILOSOPHICAL TENDENCIES IN ENGLISH LITERATURE Why do people write poems, stories and plays?
column1068: The obvious and cynical answer is that people write because they are paid for their writing; the poet makes a poem for the same reason that the carpenter makes a bench, and the dramatist has no motive other than that of the bootmaker.
column1069: There is some truth in this; if people do not begin to write because they consider writing a means of livelihood they often continue to write for that reason.
column1070: Certainly it is easy to think of contemporary authors of whom it may safely be said that they have no inspiration save the desire for money.
column1071: But the existence of literature is not thus easily to be explained.
column1072: There are so many trades and professions easier and more profitable than that of letters that he would be a very stupid person indeed who selected it with nothing to influence him in that direction but the desire to make money.
column1073: There is something else beside the perfectly legitimate desire to make a livelihood in the mind of the writer; there is something that makes him undergo poverty and other tribulations for the sake of his craft.
column1075: What is it that makes writers write?
column1077: The will to write is related to nearly all the passions, ambitions and desires of mankind; it is the result of instincts immemorial and unchanging.
column1078: There are those who hold a peculiar inspirational theory about writing, who believe that an author is merely the instrument used by some creative power.
column1079: In so far as this theory coincides with the truth that God is the source of all energy it is, of course, sound.
column1080: But those who hold it generally base it on some fantastic idea of genius as a magic, unknowable power, irresponsibly wandering through the world and selecting at random the men and women who are to be through its mysterious spell creative artists.
column1081: It is a fascinating theory, but untrue, being supported only by the citation of numerous particular cases, which cannot in logic establish a general rule.
column1082: A careful examination of the nature of genius would here be out of place.
column1083: It is sufficient for our purposes to consider genius as extraordinary talent, and to know that it is by no means the inevitable companion of the will to write.
column1084: The great majority of writers, those who are without skill and those who produce some interesting and even important work, are without genius.
column1085: Yet they have the will to write.
column1086: And there have been instances of men and women of undoubted genius so lazy that they seemed absolutely to lack the creative urge present in the minds of their less gifted brothers and sisters.
column1087: There would be writers if there were no such thing as genius just as there would be writers if it were impossible to make money by writing.
column1088: Consider the earliest days when first by means of crude symbols chiseled on a rock or by means of rough combinations of sounds a man endeavored to convey to his fellows some message not necessitated by the ordinary conditions of life--some message important for its own sake alone.
column1089: What caused this man to carve, to chant, to express ideas so that they would be intelligible to his fellows?
column1090: If we understand the motives for this man's conduct, if we find out what made him a creative artist, we shall understand why modern man writes.
column1091: For the motives, emotions, essential habits of mankind do not greatly change with the passing of the ages; the soul of man has the changelessness of immortal things.
column1092: Motives are hard to trace and they are usually found in combination.
column1093: We cannot be sure that the first writer had only one motive, but we can imagine many motives, any one of which would have been sufficient to cause his literary adventure.
column1094: These may be indicated as the urge to chronicle, the urge to attract, the urge to worship, and the urge to create.
column1095: And all these are related to and possibly included by the need of self-expression.
column1096: Among the simplest and least literary people, events that greatly disturb the routine of life--wars, famines, pestilences, earthquakes--seem to develop writers automatically.
column1097: The great thing has happened and must have a record safer than man's fickle memory.
column1098: So inevitably come the chronicler and his chronicle.
column1100: But the desire to ensure remembrance of events is not in itself sufficient to ensure the existence of literature.
column1101: There is also what I have termed the urge to attract.
column1102: The savage warrior may carve on stone or paint upon a strip of pale bark a record of his own brave victory or ingenious escape.
column1103: This he does to attract the attention and admiration of his public, such as it is, to his courage and intelligence.
column1104: And also the mere making of the record is in itself an achievement certain to bring to its maker the wonder and esteem of those lacking this strange power.
column1105: And this sort of admiration, he finds, comes to him even when the things about which he writes are not his own doings.
column1106: So subjective art comes into existence.
column1107: Man writes because of the urge to worship to-day, as he has always done.
column1108: He utters prayers that have been provided for his needs by divinely constituted authorities, and to the unspoken ejaculation of his heart he silently gives the best literary form possible to him--the directness and passionate simplicity proper to great literature.
column1109: He repeats, when he prays in accordance with the forms prescribed by the Church, great literature which came into existence originally in response to the urge to worship.
column1110: And in all languages the writings of most enduring loveliness, even apart from those divinely inspired, are those which relate most closely to worship--those writings made immortal by the love of God.
column1111: So writers may fulfill the purpose for which they are made by writing--may know God better by writing about Him, increase their love of Him by expressing it in beautiful words, serve Him in this world by means of their best talent, and because of this service and His mercy be happy with Him forever in Heaven.
column1112: There is also the motive which perhaps gives rise to the common and fallacious idea of the writer's inspiration--the motive which I have designated as the urge to create.
column1113: Of course the only true creator is God, and for a creature to seem to create may be a perilous thing, savoring of blasphemy.
column1114: Certainly the evil egotism of some writers, using their talent for the destruction of their souls and those of others, is a blasphemous thing.
column1115: This is a matter better suited for discussion by a moral theologian than by a critic, but surely it is possible for the writer to assay his task of creating a work of art the more humbly and the more joyfully because it is done in reverent imitation of the Maker or Poet of the universe.
column1116: Now, a writer does not analyze or separate his motives.
column1117: They all are related to and possibly included by the need of self-expression.
column1118: There is an idea in the writer's brain which he wishes to put into words and on paper.
column1119: He does so, without bothering to try to discover why he has this impulse.
column1120: The existence of these motives, in various combinations, is evident in all literature.
column1121: The novelist wishes to create a thing of beauty, to chronicle certain actual or possible events, to attract admiration to himself and perhaps to a certain class or race of men.
column1122: If he is a great writer he has also, even if he be not thoroughly conscious of it, the desire to worship--he uses his talent honestly and skillfully, for God's sake, making an acceptable offering.
column1123: He may write a drama of modern life, a story of pioneer days in the Far West, a sonnet to a buttercup, a pamphlet in favor of improved tenement houses, a history of the Spanish-American War.
column1124: Whatever he may write, his desire is to chronicle, attract, and to create.
column1125: And if he be a great writer his desire also is to worship.
column1126: The power and desire to influence thought possessed by skillful writers has caused the world sometimes to regard them as actually the leaders of mankind's spiritual and intellectual endeavors.
column1127: Writers themselves are quick to take this point of view; we have in America hundreds of popular novelists who have no hesitation in advising humanity about all its moral problems, thousands of minor poets who will answer the questions of the ages in a sonnet or a handful of free verse.
column1128: There are some reasons for the writers to be justly considered leaders of popular thought.
column1129: As a class, they understand humanity, and sympathize with it.
column1130: They have the passions and hopes and loves of the rest of the world, intensified.
column1131: Also they have a sense of artistic, or, as it is called, poetic justice, and poetic justice usually is Christian justice.
column1132: But writers are unfitted to be leaders of popular thought by many disqualifications inseparable from their craft.
column1133: Interested as they are in the rest of humanity, they inevitably are set apart from it by reason of their exceptional gift.
column1134: They show their sense of this separation, even when they do not openly admit it, by dressing and talking and living in a manner different from that common to their fellow-citizens.
column1135: The velvet jacket, the long hair, the flowing necktie, the Bohemian studio, the defiance of custom and sometimes of law--these things are indications of that separation from mankind which makes the writer an unsafe leader of popular thought.
column1136: There is also the danger that the writer will, if he become a leader of thought, grow intoxicated with power, and lead thought irresponsibly, foolishly, wickedly, having in mind not the welfare of humanity but the delight of leadership.
column1137: To this temptation all leaders of thought--politicians, educators, investigators--are liable, but the writers most of all.
column1138: The proper function of the writer is rather to interpret than to lead the thought of his time.
column1139: Seldom does a writer actually give the world a new idea.
column1140: What he does is to give expression to an idea which has lain dormant in the mind of the people awaiting his revealing and quickening touch.
column1141: There is a hope or a fear in the minds of men--it finds expression in deeds and simultaneously in words.
column1142: The events in a nation's history and the intellectual and spiritual causes of those events are revealed to later generations by the poets and story-tellers.
column1143: The historical development of nations is clear to the students of the world's literature.
column1144: Take the American Civil War for an example--we find the soul of the North revealed in "Marching Through Georgia" and the "Battle Hymn of the Republic" and the soul of the South in "Dixie" and in "Maryland, My Maryland."
column1145: No volumes of history give us a clearer understanding of the feelings of our fathers than do these poems.
column1146: So also I believe that the awakening to a sense of the evil of the so-called Reformation, that awakening which is historically recorded by the events associated with the Oxford Movement, found literary expression in the poetry of Rossetti and Patmore and the other members of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood.
column1147: Since the development which history records is merely the outward and visible sign of an inward and spiritual progress, therefore the proper themes of creative literary artists are those things which the professed historians cannot treat--the hidden things, the essentials of history.
column1148: So the writers whose work endures are those who concern themselves with the interior, not the exterior, of life.
column1149: The great writers are the spiritual historians of their generation.
column1150: Physical man is important only in relation to spiritual man.
column1151: Man by himself, man not considered in respect to God, is unworthy of the attention of any writer.
column1152: The men and women whose plays and poems and stories endure are those who see that one cannot "know himself" if he "presume not God to scan."
column1153: They know that the proper study of mankind, and the theme of all literature worthy of the name, is the soul of man.
column1154: Literature is a matter of spiritual chronicle and interpretation.
column1155: Therefore its beauty must, as Keats said, be truth.
column1156: The writer approaches beauty in proportion as the subject of his interpretation approaches truth.
column1157: It is a fact that a writer may express an idea which seems contrary to the feeling of his time--may praise economic justice, for instance, in the day of great industrial tyranny, or in general express idealism among materialists.
column1158: But this should not make us consider him an untruthful interpreter.
column1159: Ideas implicit in the people may be explicit in the writer.
column1160: And again the writer may express the thought of a minority more significant than the majority.
column1161: The popularity of a writer may be geographical or temporal--perhaps numerical would give a clearer idea of my meaning than geographical.
column1162: That is, he may be read in his own time by many people, spread over a great part of the world's surface, or he may have the attention of a public which is great because it extends through the ages.
column1163: The second sort of popularity is that which the great writers receive, and sometimes they have the first kind also.
column1164: The great writer, the universal writer, is universal in his theme.
column1165: And there is only one theme that is universal--God.
column1166: TWO LECTURES ON ENGLISH POETRY THE BALLAD I begin the consideration of the forms of versification with the ballad, for two reasons.
column1167: In the first place, this is historically the correct procedure.
column1168: The earliest English poetry that has come down to us is in this form; it is the ballad that, recited in the great hall of the castle on a Winter evening by some wandering bard, delighted the simple hearts of our remote forefathers, strong, rude men, few of whom ever tasted the dainties that are bred in a book.
column1169: The ballad gave pleasure not only to the lord and his lady, as they reclined in their great oaken chairs, but also the chaplain and the men-at-arms and the serving folk clustered together toward the foot of the table.
column1170: For the ballad is universal in its appeal, it is the most democratic kind of poetry.
column1171: Perhaps it is not the most primitive sort; the songs of worship or praise or love which grew out of the earliest dance rituals may have been more closely akin to the lyric.
column1172: But these songs must soon have developed into a recital of the deeds of the god or hero celebrated; they must have taken on that narrative style which is the essential of the ballad.
column1173: We may choose to call Chaucer's "Canterbury Pilgrims" an epic, if we will, but even so we cannot avoid the feeling that it is a sequence of ballads.
column1174: And after all an epic is nothing but a ballad de luxe.
column1175: The second reason for considering the ballad first among the forms of English verse is the ease with which it may be written.
column1176: It is the simplest form of poetical composition, and the novice in the craft of versification will not find it difficult to attain in it, after a few attempts, a fair measure of success.
column1178: Let me begin by saying what it is not.
column1179: It is not a brief song, although of late years the word has been generally used to designate almost any rimed composition set to music.
column1180: People who speak of some of the popular songs of the day as "sentimental ballads" are using the term incorrectly.
column1181: They mean, as a rule, "sentimental lyrics."
column1182: In bygone years the ballad was sung, or at any rate recited, to the accompaniment of a harp or other stringed instrument.
column1183: But in modern times the lyric is almost the only sort of poetry to receive a musical setting.
column1184: Furthermore, the ballad is not the ballade.
column1185: The ballade is a highly artificial form of verse, French in origin, consisting, as a rule, of three eight-line stanzas and a four-line envoi, with only three rhymes in all twenty-eight lines.
column1186: People with a taste for untra-modern spelling sometimes label these productions "ballads" instead of "ballades," and other people sometimes try to give their ballads an archaic flavor by labeling them "ballades."
column1188: A ballade is no more a ballad than a sonnet is a quatrain.
column1190: In "On the History of the Ballads, 1100-1500" (Proceedings of the British Academy, Volume IV), Professor W. P. Ker writes: "The truth is that the ballad is an ideal, a poetical form, which can take up any matter, and does not leave that matter as it was before."
column1191: But this, of course, is no definition.
column1192: It would apply equally well to all forms of poetry.
column1193: Professor Ker continues: "In spite of Socrates and his logic we may venture to say, in answer to the question 'What is a ballad?'
column1194: --'A Ballad is "The Milldams of Binnorie" and "Sir Patrick Spens" and "The Douglas Tragedy" and "Lord Randal" and "Childe Maurice," and things of that sort.'"
column1195: That greatest of anthologists, Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch, quotes these remarks of Professor Ker in the preface to his volume "The Oxford Book of Ballads," a book which every lover of poetry and especially every member of the craft of verse-making should possess.
column1196: He goes on to supplement Professor Ker's definition, or rather description, by quoting lines from a number of famous ballads of ancient days, and saying that the ballad is these things also and in proof of the statement that ballads are diverse in manner and theme he mentions as latter-day ballad-makers poets having so little in common as Sir Walter Scott, Coleridge and Rudyard Kipling.
column1197: Thus do Professor Ker and Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch evade the task of definition-making.
column1198: But they are critics of poetry and therefore entitled to the use of escapes and evasions denied to the author of a text-book.
column1199: Let me therefore say with no thought of originality in the saying, that a ballad is a story told in verse.
column1200: Usually it is told in a sequence of quatrains, with one rhyme to a stanza, and usually the line is the iambic heptameter--or rather the stanza consists of two iambic tetrameters and two iambic trimeters.
column1201: But this form is not inevitable; the only thing inevitable about a ballad is that it shall be a story.
column1202: Of the ancient ballads there are many collections, of which the most famous are those of Bishop Percy and of Professor Child.
column1203: But Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch's book, already mentioned, is sufficiently comprehensive for the needs of the ordinary student of the subject.
column1204: In the preface to this book, Sir Arthur says a rather surprising thing.
column1205: He says: "While the lyric in general, still making for variety, is to-day more prolific than ever and (all cant apart) promises fruit to equal the best, that particular offshoot which we call the ballad has been dead, or as good as dead, for two hundred years."
column1206: It is hard to understand why Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch made this statement.
column1207: In his "The Oxford Book of English Verse" and "The Oxford Book of Victorian Verse" he had included so many true ballads--Rossetti's "The Blessed Damozel," and Dobell's "Keith of Ravelston"--which is as authentic a ballad as "Thomas the Rhymer" or "Sir Patrick Spens."
column1208: Also Kipling was making genuine ballads of land and water, and Henry Newbolt was writing his glorious ballads of the British Navy.
column1209: The ballad was far from dead; it was no longer the only popular form of poetry, but it had not ceased to thrive.
column1210: And the Great War seems to have given English and American poets new enthusiasm for this form so suited to the chronicling of deeds of valor.
column1211: I have said that the true ballad was a story told in verse.
column1212: Let me add that, according to the strictest interpretation of the term, the story must be told throughout in the third person--the narrator must be merely a narrator, he cannot figure in the tale.
column1213: This is true of most of the old ballads.
column1214: There are exceptions to the rule, however, notably "Archie of Cawfield" and the immortal "Helen of Kirconnel."
column1215: Nor is it necessary that the modern ballad-maker should take pains to eliminate his own personality from his work, the modern tendency seems to be toward subjectivity in poetry and the verse-maker who seeks popular approval will be guided by popular tastes.
column1216: It is true that the very greatest of the ballads are those which were written in the days when the ballad had not to compete with other forms.
column1217: But in accordance with the principle underlying this work--that of exhibiting the work of successful modern poetic craftsmen, I will not quote "Sir Patrick Spens" or "Hugh of Lincoln" or "Cospatrick" or "Little Musgrave and Lady Barnard" or any other classic.
column1218: Instead, I will call the reader's attention to the work of some of the poets who, in our own time, have been proving the falsity of Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch's statement.
column1219: THE SONNET I said that the ballad was the most primitive form of English verse composition of which examples have come down to us, and that it was the easiest form to write.
column1220: I now come to what might almost be called the antithesis of the ballad--the sonnet.
column1221: The ballad is simple, the sonnet is complex; the ballad appeals to the uneducated, being, as I said, merely a short story in verse, while the sonnet appeals chiefly to those who have a cultivated taste for poetry.
column1222: It is easy, I said, to write a passable ballad; to write a sonnet that is merely correct in technique is a difficult matter, and to write a good sonnet calls for the exercise of all a verse-maker's patience, ingenuity and talent.
column1223: Theodore Watts-Dunton, himself an accomplished sonneteer, finds the sonnet as "in the literature of modern Europe, a brief poetic form of fourteen rhymed verses, ranged according to prescription."
column1224: This definition is open to criticism in two respects.
column1225: In the first place it is redundant, since a poem of fourteen lines necessarily is brief.
column1226: In the second place Watts-Dunton neglected to state that the length of the line is arbitrarily fixed--if the lines are not iambic pentameters, the poem is not a sonnet.
column1227: The first requirements of the sonnet, then, are that it shall have fourteen lines, and that these lines shall be iambic pentameters.
column1228: Furthermore, the rhyme scheme is arbitrarily fixed, and the number of rhymes arbitrarily limited in such a way as to add greatly to the verse-maker's labor.
column1229: The simplest form of the sonnet is what is called the Shakespearean sonnet, from its use in the famous sequence in which the greatest of English poets is said to have "unlocked his heart"--although this does not seem a fair description of it, when we consider the great library of books in which attempts are made to explain what Shakespeare meant in these sonnets.
column1230: This form consists merely of the quatrains, rhyming _a, b, a, b, c, d, c, d, e, f, e, f_, followed by a rhymed couplet.
column1231: The lines are, as in all forms of the sonnet, iambic pentameters.
column1232: Obviously, this form presents no real difficulty to the verse-maker with a fair degree of talent.
column1233: Its use by Shakespeare gives it a certain authority, and some critics, notably Professor Israel Gollanez, of London University, say that it is better suited the English language than the more usual or Petrarchan form.
column1234: Nevertheless, the weight of opinion is against this form.
column1235: Many critics deny that three quatrains followed by a couplet constitute a true sonnet, and Professor Brander Matthews always calls this form not a sonnet but a "fourteener."
column1236: Modern English poets who have written Shakespearean sonnets are few in number.
column1237: George Eliot wrote a sequence in this form, but did not thereby add to her fame.
column1238: In fact, the only notable use of the Shakespearean sonnet form during the last half century is to be found in John Masefield's "Good Friday and Other Poems," which contain a sequence of introspective and philosophical Shakespearean sonnets, so lofty in thought and appropriate in expression as actually to suggest the work of the poet who first greatly made use of their instrument.
column1239: The form generally used by poets writing in English is what is called the Petrarchan sonnet.
column1240: In its simplest but not its easiest form, this consists of a division of eight lines called the octave and a division of six lines called the sestet, the rhyme scheme of the octave being _a, b, b, a, a, b, b, a_, and that of the sestet being _c, d, c, d, c, d_.
column1241: Here we have, you see, only four rhymes in all the fourteen lines.
column1242: An excellent example of the Petrarchan sonnet of this exact type is Austin Dobson's "Don Quixote."
column1243: DON QUIXOTE   BY AUSTIN DOBSON   Behind thy pasteboard, on thy battered back,     Thy lean cheek striped with plaster to and fro,     Thy long spear levelled at the unseen foe,   And doubtful Sancho trudging at thy back,   Thou wert a figure strange enough, good lack!
column1244: To make wiseacredom, both high and low,     Rub purblind eyes, and (having watched thee go)   Dispatch its Dogberrys upon thy track:   Alas!
column1248: Yet would to-day, when Courtesy grows chill,   And life's fine loyalties are turned to jest,     Some fire of thine might burn within us still!
column1249: Ah, would but one might lay his lance in rest     And charge in earnest--were it but a mill!
column1250: This is a good sonnet to study for several reasons.
column1251: In the first place the accuracy of the form makes it an excellent model.
column1252: And in the second place it illustrates what I have to say as to the correspondence in the thought of the sonnet and its form.
column1253: Now, there have been attempts to make a sonnet the vehicle of a narrative; these attempts have seldom been successful.
column1254: A sonnet is descriptive and interpretative in theme, and it must give at the very least two aspects of interpretations of the emotion, idea, or object with which it deals.
column1255: One of these must be in the octave and the other in the sestet.
column1256: Sometimes the idea is merely expressed or described in the octave, and explained in the sestet, sometimes the idea in the octave suggests a different idea in the sestet--the point to remember is that there must be a change in the thought marked by the beginning of the sonnet's ninth line.
column1257: This we see admirably illustrated in Austin Dobson's "Don Quixote."
column1258: In the first four lines we have a graphic picture of the mad knight of La Mancha, and a statement of the effect this vision has upon those who are wise in this world.
column1259: But the very first words of the sestet show the development in the thought.
column1260: The poet ceases to describe, instead he expresses emotion, he expresses his pity, his sympathy, his admiration for Don Quixote, and his wish that the knight might find a successor in our own day.
column1261: The octave has its climax and the sestet has its climax, and the two sections of the poem are related by the continuity of thought, and divided by the contrast of ideas.
column1262: This type of sonnet was called by Watts-Dunton the sonnet of flow and ebb--the significance of this term being that the thought flowed to the end of the octave and ebbed from that point to the close of the sestet.
column1263: Commenting on this John Addington Symonds wrote: "The striking metaphorical symbol drawn from the observation of the swelling and declining wave can even in some examples be applied to sonnets on the Shakespearean model; for, as a wave may fall gradually or abruptly, so the sonnet may sink with stately volume or with precipitate subsidence to its close."
column1264: For a verse-maker to give his sonnet this requisite flow and ebb of idea, and keep at the same time his rhyme scheme accurate is no easy matter.
column1265: And the very difficulty of the form is a strong argument in favor of its frequent use by novices in versification.
column1266: If you can write a sonnet that is technically correct, you need fear none of the difficulties that any other kind of verse-making will present.
column1267: The accuracy and condensation, the concentration of thought, the straight-forwardness of statement, which are the distinguishing marks of the well-turned sonnet are the most valuable tools which a verse writer can have.
column1268: In writing, as well as he can, one sonnet, the verse-maker will learn more than he could learn in writing half a dozen ballads or twenty volumes full of unrhymed free verse.
column1269: This book is intended for the guidance not of poets but of verse-makers.
column1270: Yet I cannot forbear quoting Watts-Dunton's admirable statement of the whole content of the sonnet.
column1271: He writes: "Without being wholly artificial, like the rondeau, the sestina, the ballade, the villanelle, and the rest, the sonnet is yet so artistic in structure, its form is so universally known, recognized, and adopted as being artistic, that the too fervid spontaneity and reality of the poet's emotion may be in a certain degree veiled, and the poet can whisper, as from behind a mask, those deepest secrets of the heart which could otherwise only find expression in purely dramatic forms."
column1272: As I said, the simplest, and in some respects, the most difficult form of sonnet, has for the rhyme scheme _a, b, b, a, a, b, b, a, c, d, c, d, c, d_.
column1273: But there is a tendency to vary the rhyme scheme in the sestet--the octave usually is unchanged.
column1274: One common variation is to have the rhymes of the sestet _c, d, e, c, d, e_, instead of _c, d, c, d, c, d_.
column1275: This is the scheme we find followed in the sestet of two of "Three Sonnets on Oblivion," by a distinguished American poet, Mr. George Sterling.
column1276: THREE SONNETS OF OBLIVION   BY GEORGE STERLING   _Oblivion_   Her eyes have seen the monoliths of kings     Upcast like foam of the effacing tide;     She hath beheld the desert stars deride   The monuments of power's imaginings:   About their base the wind Assyrian flings     The dust that throned the satrap in his pride;     Cambyses and the Memphian pomps abide   As in the flame the moth's presumptuous wings.
column1277: There gleams no glory that her hand shall spare,     Nor any sun whose days shall cross her night,   Whose realm enfolds man's empire and its end.
column1278: No armour of renown her sword shall dare,     No council of the gods withstand her might--     Stricken at last Time's lonely Titans bend.
column1279: _The Night of Gods_   Their mouths have drunken the eternal wine--     The draught that Baal in oblivion sips.

column1733: This is a rather Jacobean sentence, in form not typical of Hardy, but in thought it is greatly significant.
column1734: It is likely that Hardy himself wondered at the happiness in which he left Elizabeth-Jane, reassuring himself perhaps by the conviction that her "unbroken tranquillity" was the exception which proved the rule her youth had taught her.
column1735: For it cannot be denied that according to the Hardy philosophy, implicit in his tales and explicit in his poems, sorrow is the rule and joy the exception.
column1736: In no other writing is he more clearly a fatalist than in "The Mayor of Casterbridge"; in no other book does he urge more unmistakably his belief that men and women are but helpless puppets in the hands of mischievous fate, that good-will and courage and honesty are brittle weapons for humanity's defense.
column1737: The evident fact that Thomas Hardy is a fatalist is responsible for the common and absurd idea that he is a pagan.
column1738: Now, there is no philosophy--with the exception of the robust and joyous philosophy of the Middle Ages--with which Hardy's philosophy contrasts more strongly than it does with paganism, that is, with the pagan philosophy of the spacious classic day.
column1739: When we speak of a pagan of ancient Greece or a pagan of ancient Rome we have in mind a brave patriotic man, with a vivid sense of the responsibilities and privileges of citizenship, and the habit of making the most of life, of enjoying to the full the years allowed him on earth.

column1780: MADISON JULIUS CAWEIN (1865-1914) America has had two great poets of nature--two men called to the task of reflecting in a mirror of words the beauty of meadow and forest.
column1781: One of these was William Cullen Bryant.
column1782: The other was Madison Julius Cawein.
column1783: As Bryant drew his inspiration from the wooded hills and fertile valleys of his native New England, so Madison Cawein drew his from the meadows of the South, especially those of Kentucky.
column1784: The term "nature poet" has been used in derision of some writers who lavish sentimental adulation upon every bird and flower, who pretend an admiration for things of which they have no real understanding.
column1785: But Madison Cawein knew what he was writing about; he had an amazing, we might say a perilous, intimacy with nature.
column1786: And he had no vague love for all nature--he knew too much for that.
column1787: True, he knew nature in her delicate and in her splendid aspect--he saw the barberry redden in the lanes, he feasted his eyes on "the orange and amber of the marigold, the terra-cottas of the zinnia flowers," he learned lovely secrets from whippoorwill, swallow, and cricket, and he could see drowsy Summer rocking the world to sleep in her kindly arms.
column1788: But also he knew (with a knowledge which only Algernon Blackwood among contemporary writers has equaled) that nature has her cruel and terrible aspects.
column1789: He knew that the daily life of bird and beast--yes, and the daily life of flower and tree--is as much a tragedy as a comedy.
column1790: So (in the sonnet-sequence he wrote by the Massachusetts shore in 1911) he saw a certain grove as "a sad room, devoted to the dead"; he felt the relentlessness of the ocean mists invading the shore; he saw an autumn branch staining a pool like a blur of blood; he made us share his genuine terror of deserted mill-streams where "the cardinal-flower, in the sun's broad beam, with sudden scarlet takes you by surprise," and of dark and menacing swamps, ominous with trembling moss, purple-veined pitcher-plants and wild grass trailing over the bank like the hair of a drowned girl.
column1791: His studies of nature were accurate enough to satisfy any botanist--Miss Jessie B. Rittenhouse has said that one might explore the Kentucky woods and fields with a volume of Cawein's poems as a handbook and identify many a lowly and exquisite bower first recognized in song.
column1792: But his poems were not mere catalogues of natural beauties, any more than they were sentimental idealizations of them.
column1793: They were, to repeat a phrase, reflections of nature, reflections painted rather than photographed, but interpreted rather than romanticized.
column1794: Madison Cawein had not long to wait for the recognition which he enjoyed throughout his life.
column1795: Born on March 23rd, 1865, in Louisville, Kentucky, and educated in the high school of his native city, he published his first book, "Blooms of the Berry," in 1887.
column1796: "The Triumph of Music" followed in 1888, and soon after its publication Mr. William Dean Howells wrote of the young Southern poet words that brought him to the attention of a large audience, words that applied as truly to his posthumous book, "The Cup of Comus," as to the rhymes of his boyhood.
column1797: In the _North American Review_, Mr. Howells wrote: "He has the gift, in a measure that I do not think surpassed in any poet, of touching some smallest or commonest thing in nature and making it live from the manifold associations in which we have our being, and glow thereafter with an inextinguishable beauty."
column1798: From 1887 to the time of his death, scarcely a year passed that did not see the publication of a new book of poems by Madison Cawein.
column1799: Of course, this caused him to be accused of writing too much, of giving the world poems written hastily and carelessly.
column1800: There was some justice in this accusation; undoubtedly he would have written better poems if he had written fewer.
column1801: Mr. H. Houston Peckham, of Purdue University, in an article which appeared in the _South Atlantic Quarterly_ soon after Cawein's death, told a story which is significant.
column1802: The poet was about to destroy one of his lyrics.

column1804: When it appeared in print, it was shown to Cawein, who failed to recognize it as his own work.

column1806: Now, for a poet to forget the children of his own fancy is a sign that he is writing too much.
column1807: And yet Madison Cawein was not so prolific as a list of his more than a score of volumes would indicate.
