column1827: FRANCIS THOMPSON (1859-1907) Poetic sensations are rare in our time.
column1828: For a quarter of a century we have enjoyed a regular succession of excellent books of verse--verse graceful, fanciful, musical, interesting, and sometimes noble.
column1829: Perhaps the general average of verse is higher to-day than it has previously been in the history of English letters.
column1830: But there have been few books of verse which have caused the heart of the public to beat faster, few books of verse which critics have carried in their pockets for weeks at a time to show to their friends.
column1831: There has been one such book, however.
column1832: In 1893 was published "Poems," by Francis Thompson.
column1833: And this volume (as even Thompson's enemies cannot deny) excited, favorably or unfavorably, all its reviewers.
column1834: Some hailed it as a work of surpassing genius, some found it irritatingly bad.
column1835: But all felt about it passionately; no one damned it with faint praise and no one praised it with faint damns.
column1836: Francis Thompson was a Roman Catholic and his faith gave him the themes, the imagery, often the phraseology, and the inspiration of all his best poetry.
column1837: Yet his first most admiring critics were men by no means in sympathy with his religion.
column1838: H. D. Traill, a North of Ireland Protestant, welcomed him as "a new poet of the first rank."
column1839: Richard Le Gallienne called him "Crashaw born again, but born greater."
column1840: John Davidson said "Thompson's poetry at its highest attains a sublimity unsurpassed by any other Victorian poet."
column1841: And Arnold Bennett wrote of Thompson's second book "Sister Songs," "My belief is that Francis Thompson has a richer natural genius, a finer poetical equipment, than any poet save Shakespeare."
column1842: Of course there were hostile critics.
column1843: Some of them were annoyed by the poet's phraseology, especially his use of words of Latin derivation and of forms which he coined for his own use.
column1844: But most of them were annoyed by his themes; they resented the intrusion of a flaming Catholicity among the delicate artificial philosophies of the poets of the nineties, and their resentment found voice in attacks that recalled the brave old days of "This will never do" and "Back to your gallipots!"
column1845: That this resentment continued, in some minds, even after the poet had died and his work had been received as an inalienable part of the world's treasury of English song is shown by the savagery of Austin Harrison's "review" of Everard Meynell's "Life of Francis Thompson" in the _English Review_ in 1913.
column1846: Francis Thompson was born on the 16th of December, 1859, at Preston, Lancashire, England.
column1847: In his boyhood he was taught at the school of the Nuns of the Cross and Passion, and in 1870 he entered Ushaw College.
column1848: After seven years at Ushaw--years marked by one great tragedy, the decision by those in authority that his "nervous timidity" unfitted him for the priesthood--he went to Owens College as a student of medicine.
column1849: His years in Manchester taught him little medicine, but they taught him other things destined to affect his life.
column1850: Francis Thompson read books, but they were not surgical treatises.
column1851: They were books of poetry, of essay, of theology, of scholastic philosophy.
column1852: His love for music increased, and he attended more concerts than lectures.
column1853: Also in Manchester he acquired his besetting sin--the opium habit.
column1854: He took the drug first in the form of laudanum, during a painful illness.
column1855: He continued to take it throughout many years of his life.
column1856: It staved off the assaults of tuberculosis, it prevented his success in medicine or any other methodical and exact career, and thus removed what might have been rivals to the art of poetry.
column1857: But, as his biographer says, opium "dealt with him remorselessly as it dealt with Coleridge and all its consumers.
column1858: It put him in such constant strife with his own conscience that he had ever to hide himself from himself, and for concealment he fled to that which made him ashamed, until it was as if a fig-leaf were of necessity plucked from the Tree of the Fall.
column1859: It killed in him the capacity for acknowledging those duties to his family and friends, which, had his heart not been in shackles, he would have owned with no ordinary ardor."
column1860: Francis Thompson's years immediately after his failure in his medical examinations were spent in London, in poverty and ill health.
column1861: But no man of genius can long remain hidden.
column1862: In a strange and romantic manner, some of his magnificent poetry and prose came to the attention of Wilfred and Alice Meynell.
column1863: They gave to the world the blessing of acquaintance with Francis Thompson's work, and to the poet they gave, in addition to more material benefits, the wise and affectionate friendship his lonely spirit most needed.
column1864: He resisted the opium habit, increased in physical and mental health, gained congenial employment as a reviewer for the best of the London weeklies.
column1865: The publication of his books established him, in the opinion of those whose opinion was most worth-while, as a figure of great literary importance.
column1866: He died "a very good death" at the age of forty-eight.
column1867: Had his mind been (as fortunately it was not) concerned with literature in his last hours he would have known that he had attained a fame of the kind that does not tarnish with the years, that he had realized the poet's ambition of adding substantially to the world's heritage of beauty.

column1870: In a materialistic and sophisticated age, Rossetti and his friends sought to reproduce the romantic splendors of the Middle Ages.
column1871: They took delight in the lovely externalities of the Catholic Church.
column1872: Rossetti's friend, Coventry Patmore, went further than the Pre-Raphaelites; he became a Catholic and thus carried the theories of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood to their logical and tremendous conclusion.
column1873: Patmore's greater disciple, Francis Thompson, brought back to English poetry the knowledge, largely forgotten since the Reformation, that the proper study of mankind is God; he refused to limit his mind, as his contemporaries did theirs, by temporal and astronomical boundaries.
column1874: A universal poet must sing the universe.
column1875: And the center of the universe is God.

column1878: JOHN MASEFIELD (1874--) To be versatile and prolific generally is to be unimportant.
column1879: Especially in literature, Jack-of-all-trades is, as a rule, master of none.
column1880: An exception brilliantly proving this rule is John Masefield.
column1881: Homer (scholars tell us) was not one man but a company of poets, writing through more than one century.
column1882: Shakespeare (we are encouraged to believe) was not a theatrical manager who liked occasionally to build a play to show his dramatists how it should be done, but a syndicate of philosophers, poets, playwrights, scientists, and politicians.
column1883: Three hundred years from now literary detectives will busy themselves with discovering the names of the sailor, the farmer, the Hellenist, the Orientalist, the sociologist, the realist, the romanticist, the dramatist, the ballad maker, the sonneteer, the novelist, the short story writer, who called their conspiracy John Masefield.
column1884: They will attribute some of the "Salt Water Ballads" to Kipling, some to Henry Newbolt, some to C. Fox Smith.
column1885: They will attribute "The Sweeps of Ninety-Eight" to Dr. Douglas Hyde.
column1886: They will attribute "The Faithful" to Sturge Moore.
column1887: They will attribute "The Tragedy of Nan" to D. H. Lawrence, part of "A Mainsail Haul" to Charles Whibley, part of it to Algernon Blackwood, and part of it to Robert Louis Stevenson.
column1888: And some of his ballads they will attribute to Wilfrid Gibson and some of his lyrics to William Butler Yeats.
column1889: This will be a stupid thing for them to do, but nevertheless, they will do it.
column1890: One reason why the conduct of these hypothetical scholars is particularly irritating is that John Masefield is a writer of strong individuality.
column1891: He has a distinct and easily recognizable style; his theme may be a battle of wits between Tiger Roche and the rebel hunters of 1798, or the tragedy of Nan Hardwick and the mutton parsties and the malicious Pargetters, or the great intrigues of royal Spain, or the ambitions of Pompey, or the soul of man in its relation to the mercy of God--whatever his theme may be, his style is the same.
column1892: The writer's eyes may be fixed upon the mysteries of his own heart, or they may be searching the boundless heavens; he is, nevertheless, always a realist.
column1893: They may be curiously studying the most ordinary details of modern life; he is, nevertheless, always an idealist.
column1894: So the intellectual, perhaps it might be said the spiritual, attitude of John Masefield is unvarying.
column1895: And in this is to be found the reason for the intense individuality of the writer as seen in his works, for the feeling, common to all his readers, of being in direct communication with him.
column1896: And the style of the sequence of sonnets in the Shakespearean manner is much the same as that of the stories about pirates and the drama of ancient Japan.
column1897: The nervous expressive diction, the direct Elizabethan colloquialism, these things are Masefield; the form may vary, but not in its characteristics, the language.
column1898: A writer's attitude toward life and toward the things beyond life is his own; it is not to be accounted for by heredity or environment.
column1899: But a writer's style must necessarily be influenced, by what he reads and by the talk of those with whom he spends the formative periods of his life.
column1900: Even the careless reader of John Masefield's books will notice occasionally in them, especially in the lyrics, a strong Celtic flavor.
column1901: Masefield's "Sea-Fever" and "Roadways" and "Cardigan Bay" and "Trade Winds" and "The Harper's Song" surely belong to the same family as Eva Gore Booth's "The Little Waves of Breffny" and William Butler Yeats's "The Lake Isle of Innisfree."
column1902: Furthermore, Masefield has that belief in the beauty of tragedy, tragedy in itself without regard to its moral significance, which is characteristic of many of the Irish writers of our generation.
column1903: In the preface to "The Tragedy of Nan" he writes: "Tragedy at its best is a vision of the heart of life.
column1904: The heart of life can only be laid bare in the agony and exultation of dreadful acts.
column1905: The vision of agony, or spiritual contest, pushed beyond the limits of the dying personality, is exalting and cleansing.
column1906: It is only by such visions that a multitude can be brought to the passionate knowledge of things exulting and eternal.... Our playwrights have all the powers except that power of exaltation which comes from a delighted brooding on excessive, terrible things.
column1907: That power is seldom granted to men; twice or thrice to a race perhaps, not oftener.
column1908: But it seems to me certain that every effort, however humble, towards the achieving of that power helps the genius of a race to obtain it, though the obtaining may be fifty years after the strivers are dead."
column1909: Now in our time only one other writer has expressed this idea with equal force.
column1910: And that writer is Mr. William Butler Yeats.
column1911: He has written in an essay: "Tragic art, passionate art, ... the confounder of understanding, moves us by setting us to reverie, by alluring us almost to the intensity of trance."
column1912: So we find the Irish and the English writer guided by one impulse and by one conviction.
column1913: And the result is that considering this, and considering also the Celtic idiom which seemingly comes so naturally from the lips of Mr. Masefield, Englishman though he be, in his lyrics, in his poetic dramas, and in many of the stories in "A Mainsail Haul," we are tempted to believe that the Irish literary movement has stretched a shadowy arm across the channel and laid its potent spell upon a man of Saxon blood.

column1917: Another flaw is, that this idea of the nobility, one might almost say, of the loveliness of tragedy, while it is in our time more Irish than English, was held by the English dramatists and poets of centuries ago--Marlowe, for instance, and Webster and Shakespeare himself.

column1920: Furthermore, the modern Irish-English idiom is to a great extent the idiom of England some centuries ago.
column1921: There are rhymes in Shakespeare and even in Pope which show that what we consider Irish mispronunciations of English are simply English pronunciations that have been carried through the ages unchanged--the "ay" sound for "ea" is an example of that.
column1922: "Our gracious Anne, whom the three realms obey, does sometimes counsel take, and sometimes tea."
column1923: Chaucerian scholars say that the Wife of Bath talked what we would call Irish dialect.
column1924: Now, John Masefield's literary idols belong not to his own generation or that immediately preceding it but to the early days of English letters.
column1925: His favorite poem, he has told me, is Chaucer's "Ballad of Good Counsel."
column1926: This reading has affected his style and it has affected also his thought, to the strengthening of the first and the deepening of the second.
column1927: There has been much said and written about Masefield's romantic youth--about his experiences before the mast and behind the bar.
column1928: There was a tendency during his tour of the United States in the early spring of 1916 to regard him as very much of a self-made man, to marvel at the miracle of genius which turned a bartender-sailor into a great poet.
column1929: But the fact of the matter is that Masefield is essentially of the literary type, a man who might readily have supported himself by school-teaching, journalism, or some other unromantic trade, but deliberately selected colorful and exciting occupations.
column1930: No one can talk to him and retain the idea that Masefield is a "sailor-poet" or a "bartender-poet."
column1931: He is an educated English gentleman, very thoroughly a man of letters, who has had the good fortune to add to his treasury of experience by travels in strange places and among strange people.
column1932: Masefield's first important romantic experience, however, was undergone at a time when the poet was so young that it can scarcely have been the result of his own volition.
column1933: Born in 1874 at Ledbury, in the west of England, he was indentured to a captain in the English merchant marine at the age of fourteen years.
column1934: A fourteen-year-old boy on shipboard generally learns to hate passionately and consistently the sea and all that is associated with it.
column1935: And it would not be strictly true to say that Masefield gained from this early adventure a love of the sea.
column1936: Rather he then came under the spell of the sea, a spell from which he has never escaped.
column1937: He has not that sentimental affection for the sea which inspires the life-on-the-ocean-waves' verse written by landsmen who know Neptune only by week-end visits in the summer time.
column1938: He has been in the power of the sea more than it is altogether safe for so sensitive a spirit to be.
column1939: He seems haunted by the sea; in those of his writings which in theme are least related to the sea the reader finds that again and again the figures and comparisons are drawn from the poet's memory of days when above and beyond him were nothing but water and sky.
column1940: Not even Algernon Charles Swinburne was so much influenced by the sea as Masefield has been.
column1941: It is true that Masefield has given more beautiful expression to love for the sea than any other poet of our time--"Sea-Fever" alone would establish him as the sea's true lover.
column1942: But also Masefield has expressed with terrible force the cruelty of the sea, its brutal and terrifying energy, its soul-shattering melancholy.
column1943: And nowhere in English literature is it possible to find more vivid pictures of the bitter hardship of a seaman's life than in the "Salt Water Poems and Ballads."
column1944: Masefield is not elective nor selective in his attitude toward the sea; his feeling toward the sea seems almost an obsession.
column1945: The sea is not subject to his genius; it speaks through him.
column1946: Masefield's life on shipboard did more than put him in the power of the sea, it began his interest in the lives and thoughts of simple hard-working people.
column1947: And this interest has never left him.
column1948: It is true that he occasionally gives us something like "The Faithful" or "Philip, the King" or "The Tragedy of Pompey the Great."
column1949: But his heart is in poems like "Dauber" and "The Everlasting Mercy" and in stories like "A Deal of Cards," in which he writes of unsophisticated people who feel strongly and do not conceal their emotions.
column1950: It was, perhaps, because of a real sense of the value and interest of life among simple people that Masefield made the selection he did of work to support himself during his first visit to the United States.
column1951: In Connecticut he was a farm laborer, in Yonkers he was a hand in a carpet-factory and in New York City he was a sort of helper to the bartender in the old Colonial hotel on Sixth Avenue near Jefferson Market Court.
column1952: This hotel is still in the possession of the family who employed Masefield and their recollections of him are highly entertaining.
column1953: The writer once asked the eldest son of the family if Masefield had written anything during the days of his employment there.
column1954: He had not, it seemed, and he was associated in the minds of the family with the art of poetry, for one reason only--that being that he used to sing to the fretful baby, holding it in his lap as he sat in a rocking-chair in the kitchen, waiting for his employer's wife to serve his dinner.
column1955: When Masefield went back to England he went to work as a clerk in a London office.
column1956: He was writing now, putting on paper the pictures that had been etched in his brain and in his heart during his wander years.
column1957: Now he perceived the deep and abiding beauty and the deep and abiding tragedy (to Masefield they were the same) of his experiences.
column1958: How this knowledge came to him he has told in twelve immensely sincere lines.
column1959: E. A. Robinson has said that poetry is a language which tells, by means of a more or less emotional reaction, that which cannot be stated in prose.
column1960: And therefore it is better to let Masefield tell this in poetry than to attempt to paraphrase it.
column1961: He wrote, by way of preface to "A Mainsail Haul":   "I yarned with ancient shipmen beside the galley range,   And some were fond of women, but all were fond of change;   They sang their quavering chanties, all in a fo'c's'le drone,   And I was finally suited, if I had only known.
column1962: I rested in an ale-house that had a sanded floor,   Where seamen sat a-drinking and chalking up the score;   They yarned of ships and mermaids, of topsail sheets and slings,   But I was discontented; I looked for better things.
column1963: I heard a drunken fiddler in Billy Lee's saloon,   I brooked an empty belly with thinking of the tune;   I swung the doors disgusted as drunkards rose to dance,   And now I know the music was life and life's romance."
column1964: Masefield's work soon attracted the attention of William Butler Yeats, John Galsworthy, Sturge Moore, and other English men of letters, and largely through their efforts was brought to the attention of the public.
column1965: American readers first became aware of him through the publication of two long poems--"The Everlasting Mercy" and "The Widow in the Bye Street."
column1966: To say that these were long narrative, poems, dealing with intensely tragic and dramatic events in the life of the British poor, is not to describe them adequately.
column1967: They were a poetry new to our generation.
column1968: They showed an intimate knowledge of the lives of the poor, especially of the criminal poor, not to be found in the amiable poems of Mr. W. W. Gibson and similar socialistic dilettantes.
column1969: They were not socialistic in message; rather they were individualistic.
column1970: Saul Kane was not a drunkard because of economic pressure; Jimmy's siren lived an evil life merely because she was evil, not as a result of the injustice of man-made laws or anything else of the sort.
column1971: So precedents were violated and Masefield scored a success of sensation.
column1972: The savage colloquialisms of the poems, their violent emotionalism, their melodrama--these things brought them to the attention of a large number of people not ordinarily interested in the work of new poets, and thus an audience was prepared for the poet's later and more important work.
column1973: There can be no doubt that the work published later was more important.
column1974: There were crudities in these two narrative poems which seemed to be put there deliberately, in order to startle and shock the reader.
column1975: Masefield followed these poems with other poems in the same manner done with much greater technical skill and with a more convincing sincerity.
column1976: "Dauber" and "Biography" and the "Daffodil Fields" are more likely to be read by the next generation than are "The Widow in the Bye Street" and "The Everlasting Mercy," in spite of the fact that the last mentioned poem was awarded the Edward de Polignac prize of $500 by the Royal Society of Literature.
column1977: It is hard to tell just what form Masefield will finally select for the expression of his genius.
column1978: He has written ballads, lyrics, plays, novels, short-stories, even histories, and all these forms he has molded to his own use.
column1979: At the time of writing he is in France actively engaged in Red Cross work, and has begun to send to the magazines stories of the things that he has seen which entitle him to be called a great reporter.
column1980: The quest for beauty has been and is his ruling passion--he is splendidly explicit on this subject in the magnificent sequence of Shakespearean sonnets printed in "Good Friday and Other Poems."
column1981: He has searched for this beauty on the boundless sea, in noisy barrooms, in English meadows, in the streets of New York.
column1982: He is seeking it now, we may believe, in the tragedy and heroism of the battlefield.
column1983: And always, his sonnets tell us, it is evasive and very distant, because its real dwelling place is his own soul.
column1984: WILLIAM VAUGHN MOODY (1869-1910) William Vaughn Moody was throughout his life regarded as the most promising of the younger American poets.
column1985: And when he died in 1810 most critics mourned for the unwritten lyrics and poetic dramas of which American literature had thus been robbed; they mentioned the author as a gifted youth, whom fate had removed at the beginning of a splendid career.
column1986: To a certain extent this attitude was a tribute to the youthful spirit of William Vaughn Moody, to his vivacity, energy and cheerfulness.
column1987: But it was chiefly a new illustration of the fact that nowadays poets flower late in the season.
column1988: Moody was forty-one years old when he died--and there was a time when the poet of forty was considered well past the meridian of his genius.
column1989: Most of the great poets established their fame before they were thirty years old--Keats and Shelley died at twenty-five and twenty-nine respectively.
column1990: But nowadays the poet of forty-five is still called young and the poet of thirty our kind critics consider a precocious infant.
column1991: As a matter of stern fact, it is doubtful that American literature has really lost much by Moody's death.
column1992: He wrote "Gloucester Moors" and the "Ode in Time of Hesitation" and "The Faith Healer."
column1993: The conscientious student of his work cannot escape the conviction that in these he gave the world all that he really had to give.
column1994: Of course he would have written more--nature lyrics, poems on political and sociological questions, poetical dramas dealing with philosophical themes, prose plays of modern American life.
column1995: But toward the end of his brief life his work was not gaining in force.
column1996: Readers of "The Death of Eve" have little sorrow over the poet's failure to complete this play--the first two members of the trilogy which it was to conclude are nobly phrased, but they are so cloudy in thought and weak in dramatic construction that they do their author's fame little service.
column1997: Prometheus, Pandora, Deucalion, Eve, Cain, Raphael, and Michael, angels and archangels, thrones, dominions and powers, were characters too mighty for the talent of this poet, who could handle adequately enough a problem of contemporary politics or draw quaint lessons from the caged beasts in a menagerie.
column1998: Perhaps the coldness which annoys some readers of Moody's poems, the sense of aloofness from the common experience of mankind, the artificiality which mars such expressions of sympathy for humanity as are intended in "Gloucester Moors," are things for which it is unjust to blame the poet.
column1999: His friend, John M. Manly, wrote in the preface to his "Poems and Plays": "He was an epicure of life, a voluptuary of the whole range of physical, mental, and spiritual perfections."
column2000: But in Moody's poetry we find more of the mind than of the heart; we feel that we are in the presence of a charming and cultured personality, but we have no feeling of intimacy with the writer.
column2001: "Of thine own tears thy song must tears beget," wrote Rossetti.
column2002: "O singer, magic mirror hast thou none save thine own manifest heart."
column2003: And a greater poet than Rossetti exclaimed, "Ah, must (Designer Infinite!)
column2004: Thou char the wood ere thou canst limn with?"
column2005: A similar thought was in Horace's mind when in the _Ars Poetica_ he said, "if you wish me to weep, you must first weep yourself."
column2006: Well, few tears are drawn by Moody's poems, nor did many tears go into their making.
column2008: But he was a conscientious and accomplished artist, doing the best he could with the powers that were his.
column2009: His work is thoughtful, imaginative, and well-wrought, his "Great Divide" is destined to periodic revivals, and the best of his lyrics are sure of a place in the anthologies.
column2010: William Vaughn Moody was born in Spencer, Indiana, on July 8th, 1869.
column2011: He was the son of a prosperous retired steamboat captain.
column2012: In 1871 the family moved to New Albany, on the Ohio River.
column2014: William Vaughn Moody went to Riverside Academy and entered Harvard in 1889, being then twenty years old.
column2015: In his senior year he went abroad with a wealthy family as tutor to their son.
column2016: During the trip he made a walking tour of the Black Forest and Switzerland with a party of friends, including Norman Hapgood.
column2017: He also spent some time in Greece and Italy.
column2018: He returned to Harvard to study for his master's degree and stayed on as an instructor in English.
column2019: In the autumn of 1895 he went to the University of Chicago as instructor in English, reaching the rank of assistant professor before his departure eight years later.
column2020: His life at the University of Chicago seems to have been rather leisurely.
column2021: It was varied by journeys abroad and bicycle tours in Illinois and Wisconsin.
column2022: Swimming, bicycling, golf, tennis, walking, and mountain-climbing are mentioned by Mr. Manly as Moody's favorite sports, and it is not to be wondered that he had little time for writing, however unexacting his academic duties may have been.
column2023: Although his connection with the University of Chicago did not cease until later, he taught no classes after 1902.
column2024: He did, however, do a certain amount of work academic in character, editing some editions of the classics and collaborating with his friend Robert M. Lovett in a "History of English Literature."
column2025: He first became known to the general public by the successful presentation of his prose play, "The Great Divide."
column2026: He died in Colorado Springs on the seventeenth of October, 1910.
column2027: A few months before his death he married Miss Harriet C. Brainerd.
column2028: It is interesting to trace the influences in Moody's work.
column2029: He was very thoroughly a man of books, and some critics complain that there is more ink than blood in the veins of the people of whom he writes.
column2030: Certainly it is possible to find traces of his reading on nearly every page that he wrote.
column2031: The lovely fourth stanza of "Gloucester Moors" is Coleridge; "Faded Pictures" is Browning at his worst; and "The Daguerreotype" is a deliberate effort to imitate the irregular ode-form of Coventry Patmore.
column2032: And of course "Heart's-Wildflower" and "A Dialogue in Purgatory," like the lyrics in "The Masque of Judgment," are a Chicago version of Rossetti.
column2033: In his prose plays we find Moody writing with an energy which he seldom exhibited in his poetry.
column2034: Not in Jerome K. Jerome's "The Passing of the Third Floor Back," nor in Charles Rann Kennedy's "The Servant in the House," is the idea of the beneficent effect of a powerful and virtuous nature more plausibly presented than in "The Faith Healer."
column2035: And Moody obtained his effect more honestly than did Jerome and Kennedy; his faith-healer is merely a faith-healer to the end of the play, there is no suggestion that he is more than human.
column2036: In many respects "The Faith Healer" is Moody's most important work.
column2037: There is more poetry in its prose than in all his poetic dramas put together.
column2038: When Michaelis makes love to Rhoda and tells the story of his childhood home, when Beeler describes the picture of Pan and the Pilgrim, and when Uncle Abe chants his prophecies and visions, then there is real poetry--poetry not unlike some of the best passages in Synge's plays.
column2039: The "strange mounting sing-song" of Uncle Abe's speech evidently was the inspiration of the best parts of Mr. Ridgley Torrence's "The Rider of Dreams."
column2040: "The Great Divide" has been magnificently acted, but it _is_ inferior in every respect to "The Faith Healer."
column2041: Its theme--the contrast between the Puritan spirit which Moody considered typical of the Eastern States, and the generous paganism which he thought characteristically Western,--might be, and probably will be, the basis of an important play.
column2042: But there never was a New Englander remotely resembling Ruth Jordan, there never was a Westerner remotely resembling Stephen Ghent.
column2043: Hero and heroine, or villain and villainess, or whatever they are supposed to be, have actuality, it is true--the actuality of figures seen in a nightmare.
column2044: And the other characters in the play have no actuality whatsoever.
column2045: And the author's total lack of humor never injured his work more than in this play.
column2046: It is painful to see situations essentially humorous made banal and dull by the author's obtuseness.
column2047: If only the idea had occurred to Bernard Shaw instead of to William Vaughn Moody!
column2048: Perhaps one reason why "The Great Divide," convincing enough when well acted, is a lamentable thing on the printed page is because it is an attempt to prove a theory.
column2049: Moody was a Puritan, through and through, and like all modern literary Puritans he was desperately ashamed of his Puritanism.
column2050: He glorified what he thought to be the pagan ideal, and in "The Great Divide" he wanted to show that the large acceptances of Ghent were nobler than the austere negations of Ruth.
column2051: But paganism and Puritanism are nothing but terms, almost meaningless from much repetition, and "The Great Divide" is a play of terms, of symbols, of lay figures.
column2052: And the only things that it proves are Moody's total inability to understand paganism and his reluctant but inevitable sympathy with Puritanism.
column2053: It was his Puritanism that made Moody try to stimulate the conscience of his land by means of "An Ode in Time of Hesitation," his best sustained long poem, and his most passionate utterance.
column2054: It was the Puritan who wrote "On a Soldier Fallen in the Philippines."
column2055: It was the Puritan who wrote "The Brute."
column2056: And I think that it was the Puritan who wrote "Gloucester Moors."
column2057: A pagan, such as Moody desired to be, would not have worried about the "souls distraught in the hold," nor would he have worried over the fact that some of the crew had over-eaten.
column2058: Also, a pagan would have enjoyed the loveliness of the wild geranium and the barberry without asking:   "Who has given to me this sweet,   And given my brother dust to eat?
column2059: And when will his wage come in?"
column2060: These things are manifestations of that Puritan characteristic known as "the New England conscience"--the cause in recent years of many rather frantic efforts at social and economic and philosophical readjustment.
column2061: Mr. John M. Manly says that "Gloucester Moors" is "a favorite poem with workers in the slums,"--a significant and startling observation.
column2062: Moody's Puritanism gives strength to many of his poems, but in others it produces strange inconsistencies and evasions.
column2063: It helped him to write "The Brute"--a strong and sincere poem.
column2064: But it caused him to fail ridiculously in "A Dialogue in Purgatory," in "Good-Friday Night," and in "Song Flower and Poppy."
column2065: In the second half of the last-named poem we come upon the root of the matter--Moody's complete failure to understand any religious system, any philosophy of life, more warm and comprehensive than his own Puritanism.
column2066: He rebelled against this Puritanism, yet he could not escape it.
column2067: He sought vaguely after paganism, whereas he could no more have been a Bacchic reveller than he could have been a Druid.
column2068: In spite of his reading of early French and Italian romances, he failed utterly to see the generous glories of the Middle Ages, when all that was noble and beautiful in paganism was made a part of the richest civilization the world has yet known.
column2069: He thought of intellectual development and spiritual freedom as things beginning about 1517--and naturally this hampered him when he wrote about Michael, Raphael, Azaziel, Eve, Jubal, and Cain.
column2070: A longer residence in Italy might have given him a more liberal culture and a spiritual philosophy generous without being pagan, pure without being Puritanical.
column2071: And therefore the critics who said that a poet of promise died in 1910 may have told the truth.
column2072: A broader culture and more extensive human sympathies would have enabled this deft artist in words to give to the world a message of the kind it always welcomes--to express beautifully the beauty that is truth.

column2201: Further, the story of Joyce Kilmer, doubtless in very fair measure, is known to nearly everyone.
column2202: An account of his career is not to be appreciably elaborated here.
column2203: There are, however, some facts in explanation of the appearance of this volume at this time which require to be set down.
column2204: And a number of circumstances in relation to the material here collected may be told, I think, to general interest.
column2205: With these matters I am probably as familiar as anyone, and so have the great privilege of undertaking to record them.
column2206: The ten highly humorous and altogether charming essays which form the first part of this volume have led a rather queer life so far--though I think their existence will be a very happy one from now on.
column2207: First, they were not "essays" at the time of their birth.
column2208: They came into the world as "articles."
column2209: So they were spoken of by the young journalist who at various times and with very little to do about the matter wrote them in the course of a bewildering variety of other activities.
column2210: Or, to be still more frank, he was perhaps more apt to refer to them, when he did refer to them at all, as "Sunday stories," done as a part of his job with the _New York Times Sunday Magazine_.
column2211: What they were called, however, is neither here nor there.
column2212: The thing is that they are here.
column2213: At the time they were offered for book publication their author, then about thirty years of age, was well established as the author of "Trees and Other Poems"--poems which had been appearing for some time in various publications, collected and issued in book form in 1914.
column2214: He had been for several years a conspicuous figure and an invaluable worker in the Poetry Society of America and the Dickens Fellowship.
column2215: He was a member of the Authors Club, and several other organizations.
column2216: He had been a lexicographer and an associate magazine editor.
column2217: He was a "star" book reviewer, conducted the Poetry Department of _The Literary Digest_, associated much with literary celebrities, and appeared in _Who's Who_.
column2218: The point I am getting at is that he had a good deal of what is called a "name."
column2219: Satan finds mischief for idle hands to do.
column2220: I suppose that is why the thought occurred to Joyce to get out a book of prose.
column2221: So, as the professional literary term has it, he "pasted up" ten of his articles--that is, cut them out of the newspaper and stuck them column width down the middle of sheets of "copy" paper.
column2222: He typed a title page, "The Circus and Other Essays," and submitted his manuscript to a publisher.
column2224: Joyce again did up his manuscript, gummed on some fresh stamps, and again away it went to another leading publishing house.
column2226: I do not know precisely how many times this manuscript was submitted for publication; but I know it was a number, a good number, of times.
column2227: That, however, "The Circus" seemed likely not to find any publisher at all at that time is not a matter for anything like astonishment.
column2228: Not when one bears in mind a publishing hobgoblin of the day.
column2229: The book was labeled "essays" and therefore damned.
column2230: And here, perhaps, it may not be too irrelevant to take a brief glance at the whole history of this mysterious thing, the light, familiar essay in English.
column2231: In the Augustan age of English prose, we remember, appeared the easy, graceful style of Steele and Addison, so admirably suited to the pleasant narrative form of essay which they introduced.
column2232: And in the nineteenth century in England, when Johnson and Goldsmith were followed by Lamb, Hazlitt, De Quincey, Leigh Hunt, Macaulay, Carlyle, Ruskin and all the rest, the essay certainly appears to have been, so to say, very much the go.
column2233: Irving, Emerson, Thoreau, Hawthorne, Lowell, Holmes--certainly our fathers were not afraid of essays.
column2234: Nevertheless, somewhere about the opening of our own day an iron-bound tradition became erected in the publishing business, at least in the United States, that books of essays would not sell; could not be made to sell even sufficiently to avoid a considerable loss on the investment of manufacture; in fact, were quite impossible as a publishing venture.
column2235: No matter how much a publisher himself, or his manuscript reader, might enjoy a collection of essays that chanced to turn up in his shop, his conviction as to its unmarketability as a book was not altered--not even stirred.
column2236: A few, a very few, essayists there were, indeed, who got published.
column2237: Agnes Repplier and Samuel McChord Crothers most prominent, perhaps, among them.
column2238: But these writers had somehow got established as essayists.
column2239: They were found on the lists only of a house with peculiarly "literary" traditions, which it was business policy to capitalize and perpetuate for the sake of the firm's "imprint."
column2240: I have heard scoffers among publishers ask if "anybody outside of New England" bought the books of these writers.
column2241: Maybe their prime function was, in the publishing term, to "dress the list."
column2242: The volumes of essays by Dr. Henry van Dyke, I know from experience as a bookseller, sold in popular measure.
column2243: And now and then a volume of collected papers by, say, Meredith Nicholson would bob up for a short space of time.
column2244: But such instances as these did not affect the general situation.
column2245: In general, when the manuscript of "The Circus" was "going the rounds" it was (supposedly) economic madness, at any rate professional heresy, not to regard books of essays as what the trade terms "plugs," and a drug on the market.
column2246: Doubtless, the publishing position in this matter was evolved from cumulative facts of experience in the past.
column2247: But a screw was loose somewhere.
column2248: The publishing barometer had, it would seem, failed to note a change in the weather of the public mind.
column2249: That "The Circus" would not have made a fairly popular book at the time it was first submitted for publication, it seems to me, there is a good deal of reason to believe was a fallacy.
column2250: Not a couple of years afterward a collection of random articles in general character not dissimilar to "The Circus," by another young man of greatly likable nature, but then practically unknown outside the circle of his personal friends, was in some idiosyncratic moment accepted, and directly won its way to a very considerable sale and a very fair degree of fame.
column2251: About then, too, along came another book of pasted-up "papers" (about which I happen to know a good deal), which after having been rejected by nearly every publishing house in America was taken in a spirit of generous friendliness by a publisher of much enterprise, began almost at once to sell as well as a fairly successful novel, has been numerous times reprinted, and in the way of luck brought its altogether obscure author something of a name.
column2252: And just now the light, personal, journalistic-literary essay is having quite a brisk vogue.
column2253: If Joyce stood to-day merely where he stood five years ago "The Circus," without doubt, would be snapped up by anybody.
column2254: More; some publisher's "scout" very likely would get a "hunch" about the probability of Joyce's having sufficient material in his scrap-book for such a volume and "go after" it even before Joyce had submitted it to the house of this fellow's connection.
column2257: Fair fortune did not attend "The Circus."
column2258: Failing of placing the book with any large house having an extensive and organized machinery for carrying it to a wide audience, Joyce welcomed the opportunity of having the book published by his friend Laurence J. Gomme.
column2259: Mr. Gomme had been for several years the proprietor of the Little Book Shop Around the Corner, at number two East Twenty-ninth Street, directly across the street from the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, so altogether charming in its Old World effect, nestling in a tiny green spot hemmed in by high buildings, and known to fame and legend as the Little Church Around the Corner.
column2260: This was a shop conducted in excellent taste, a sort of salon for pleasant persons of literary breeding, and its "circulars" were written by no less an advertising man than Richard Le Gallienne.
column2261: In addition to selling the best books of other publishers, Mr. Gomme (at a good deal of risk to himself) served the cause of good literature by himself issuing now and then a volume of a nature close to his heart.
column2262: In the autumn of 1916 he published, in a very attractive form, the American edition of Mr. Belloc's poems.
column2263: The volume was entitled "Verses," by Hilaire Belloc.
column2264: The introduction to the book by Kilmer was reprinted in the two volume set, "Joyce Kilmer: Poems, Essays and Letters," under the title "The Poetry of Hilaire Belloc."
column2265: That same fall Mr. Gomme published "The Circus and Other Essays."
column2266: He made a charming little book: a thin volume in size betwixt and between what the book trade calls a "16mo" volume and a duodecimo; bound in plain tan boards, with olive cloth back stamped in gold; very neatly printed on soft cream paper in rather small type.
column2267: The book had a rather fantastically amusing and somewhat lurid "jacket," picturing in black and yellow the professional activities of several clowns.
column2268: A very pleasant bibelot, but, I felt then, not a volume effective in catching the popular trade.
column2269: For one thing, it looked very much like it might be a book of verse.
column2270: Also, the book was so thin that one would not be likely to catch sight of it standing among other volumes in a row on a bookstore shelf.
column2271: Mr. Gomme's means as a publisher at that time did not permit him to give the book any paid advertising; it had no campaign whatever of free publicity behind it.
column2272: Nor had the publisher any traveling salesmen to show the book to dealers over the country.
column2273: He merely "covered" New York City himself in the interests of the volumes he issued.
column2274: Indeed, one would not be making a hilarious exaggeration in saying that "The Circus" was semi-"privately printed."
column2275: A fair number of copies of the book were sent out for review.
column2276: And here is a very interesting thing.
column2277: The book, as has been said, was decidedly insignificant in bulk.
column2278: It was published at a time when the assumption prevailed that there was no appreciable public for volumes of essays; and consequently, the inference would be, the publication of such a book was quite without news value.
column2279: Further, it was issued at a period when newsprint paper was appallingly scarce, newspaper space rigorously conserved, and the war engrossing public attention.
column2280: There was, too, as we have seen, nothing about the launching of "The Circus" to tempt any literary editor or reviewer to believe that the book was of any consequence whatever.
column2281: Indeed, half a "stick" of fairly favorable comment here and there would have been all that anybody could reasonably have expected in the way of a "press."
column2282: But, as a matter of fact, all in all the book got a surprising amount of space in the papers, and was awarded the dignity of thoughtful appreciation.
column2283: The _New York Evening Post_ devoted half the front page of its book review section to an article, which was continued through a column of another page, to "The Circus" and another book of essays with which it was grouped.
column2284: Shortly after the publication of "The Circus" the difficulties of the business of bookselling and publishing at this time forced Mr. Gomme to close out his business.
column2285: And for a period his affairs were very much involved.
column2286: His stock in hand was scattered, and before long his recent publications became exceedingly difficult to obtain.
column2287: A couple of years after the date of its imprint, Mr. Belloc, in the course of correspondence which I had with him mainly relating to other matters, repeatedly besought me to obtain for him a copy of his "Verses," the volume containing Kilmer's introduction.
column2288: Indeed, he was apparently much put out by the fact that, as he expressed it, he had never even seen a copy of the American edition of his poems.
column2289: I had more than a little difficulty in finding a copy to send to him.
column2291: With some petulance he laid its loss to the German submarines, which he declared sank everything that was being sent to him.
column2292: I found the trail to another copy of "Verses" still more elusive; and, to tell the truth, I really don't know whether or not I got another copy off to him.
column2293: This story is to show that anyone who has a copy of that book now has a volume far from readily found.
column2294: Copies of the original edition of "The Circus" are somewhat easier to lay hold of.
column2295: Doubtless, though, they will soon be scarce, as the original edition could not have been large.

column2297: With all the untoward circumstances of its publication, however, "The Circus" did seem to find its way to no mean circle of friends.
column2298: When the memorial volumes, "Joyce Kilmer: Poems, Essays and Letters," were published in the autumn of 1918, numerous inquiries were received by the publishers as to why the essays which comprised the volume "The Circus" were not included.
column2299: The explanation is this: In the continuance of the entanglement of the affairs of Mr. Gomme's former business no clear title to the rights of this book was at that time in sight.
column2300: Since then these matters have all been straightened out, and, I am happy to be able to say, this excellent friend of Joyce Kilmer is again in circumstances more auspicious than before, and with joy to his fine heart, effectively serving the cause of good books.
column2301: In direct critical appreciation of these ten essays there is not much that I care to say.
column2302: They were written by my friend, and are therefore holy.
column2303: That is, of course, to me.
column2304: They may be charged with being very youthful.
column2306: For ever warm and still to be enjoy'd,     For ever panting and for ever young.
column2307: Their youthfulness is to me a thing of very poignant, tender beauty.
column2308: I see again that radiant boy, trailing clouds of glory come from God who was his home.
column2309: His childhood spent in "a town less than a hundred miles from New York," "now he feels himself actually a New Yorker," "enjoys the proud novelty of working for wages," and "joyfully, therefore, he goes forth every noon to explore the territory of his new possession."
column2310: The subway was to him "the great nickel adventure"; a ride on the elevated railroad, "aërial journeying"; his alarm clock, "the urban chanticleer."
column2311: Again, as a commuter, I see him on the 5.24, flying across "leagues" to his cottage in the "primeval forest" of New Jersey.
column2312: On his "red velvet chair" he sits, "enjoying with his neighbors tobacco smoke, rapid travel, and the news of the world."
column2313: None ever enjoyed these things more, red velvet chair and all!
column2314: The connection which I may boast of having with the writing of some of these essays illustrates in an amusing way the pleasantly pugnacious character of Joyce's mind.
column2315: Joyce held that I was offensively æsthetic in regarding sign-boards about the countryside as ugly things.

column2318: You remember with what amusing gusto it begins:   If a dentist stuck a bit of holly in his cap and went through the   streets on Christmas morning, his buzzing drill over his shoulder   and his forceps in his hand, stopping at the houses of his friends   to give their jaws free treatment, meanwhile trolling out lusty   Yuletide staves--if he were to do this, I say, it would be said of   him, among other things, that he was celebrating Christmas in a   highly original manner.
column2319: Undoubtedly there would be many other   adjectives applied to his manner of generosity--adjectives applied,   for instance, by the children whom, around their gayly festooned   tree, he surprised with his gift of expert treatment.
column2320: But the   adjective most generally used (not perhaps in adulation) would be   "original."
column2321: And the use of this adjective would be utterly wrong.
column2322: The holly-bedecked dentist would not be acting in the original   manner.
column2323: He would be following the suggestion of his own   philanthropic heart.
column2324: He would be acting in accordance with   tradition, a particularly annoying tradition, the evil and absurd   superstition that a gift should be representative of the giver   rather than of the recipient.
column2325: That "particularly annoying tradition," that "evil and absurd superstition," I had been guilty of voicing a few days before he wrote this article.
column2326: He looked at me with withering commiseration.

column2481: THE CIRCUS AND OTHER ESSAYS THE CIRCUS I Restraint is perhaps the most conspicuous literary virtue of the artists in words who have the pleasant task of describing in programs, in newspaper advertisements, and on posters the excellences of circuses.
column2482: The litterateur who, possessed of an intimate knowledge of the circus, merely calls it "a new, stupendous, dazzling, magnificent, spectacular, educational, and awe-inspiring conglomeration of marvels, mysteries, mirth, and magic," deserves praise for a verbal economy almost Greek.
column2483: For he is not verbose and extravagant, he is taciturn and thrifty; he deliberately uses the mildest instead of the strongest of the adjectives at his disposal.
column2484: Shyly, it seems, but in fact artfully, he uses modest terms--"new," for example, and "spectacular" and "educational."
column2485: These are not necessarily words of praise.
column2486: An epidemic may be new, an earthquake may be spectacular, and even a session of school may be educational.
column2487: Yet the adjectives proper to these catastrophes are actually applied--in letters of gold and silver and purple--to the circus!

column3807: PHILOSOPHICAL TENDENCIES IN ENGLISH LITERATURE Why do people write poems, stories and plays?
column3808: The obvious and cynical answer is that people write because they are paid for their writing; the poet makes a poem for the same reason that the carpenter makes a bench, and the dramatist has no motive other than that of the bootmaker.
column3809: There is some truth in this; if people do not begin to write because they consider writing a means of livelihood they often continue to write for that reason.
column3810: Certainly it is easy to think of contemporary authors of whom it may safely be said that they have no inspiration save the desire for money.
column3811: But the existence of literature is not thus easily to be explained.
column3812: There are so many trades and professions easier and more profitable than that of letters that he would be a very stupid person indeed who selected it with nothing to influence him in that direction but the desire to make money.
column3813: There is something else beside the perfectly legitimate desire to make a livelihood in the mind of the writer; there is something that makes him undergo poverty and other tribulations for the sake of his craft.
column3815: What is it that makes writers write?
column3817: The will to write is related to nearly all the passions, ambitions and desires of mankind; it is the result of instincts immemorial and unchanging.
column3818: There are those who hold a peculiar inspirational theory about writing, who believe that an author is merely the instrument used by some creative power.
column3819: In so far as this theory coincides with the truth that God is the source of all energy it is, of course, sound.
column3820: But those who hold it generally base it on some fantastic idea of genius as a magic, unknowable power, irresponsibly wandering through the world and selecting at random the men and women who are to be through its mysterious spell creative artists.
column3821: It is a fascinating theory, but untrue, being supported only by the citation of numerous particular cases, which cannot in logic establish a general rule.
column3822: A careful examination of the nature of genius would here be out of place.
column3823: It is sufficient for our purposes to consider genius as extraordinary talent, and to know that it is by no means the inevitable companion of the will to write.
column3824: The great majority of writers, those who are without skill and those who produce some interesting and even important work, are without genius.
column3825: Yet they have the will to write.
column3826: And there have been instances of men and women of undoubted genius so lazy that they seemed absolutely to lack the creative urge present in the minds of their less gifted brothers and sisters.
column3827: There would be writers if there were no such thing as genius just as there would be writers if it were impossible to make money by writing.
column3828: Consider the earliest days when first by means of crude symbols chiseled on a rock or by means of rough combinations of sounds a man endeavored to convey to his fellows some message not necessitated by the ordinary conditions of life--some message important for its own sake alone.
column3829: What caused this man to carve, to chant, to express ideas so that they would be intelligible to his fellows?
column3830: If we understand the motives for this man's conduct, if we find out what made him a creative artist, we shall understand why modern man writes.
column3831: For the motives, emotions, essential habits of mankind do not greatly change with the passing of the ages; the soul of man has the changelessness of immortal things.
column3832: Motives are hard to trace and they are usually found in combination.
column3833: We cannot be sure that the first writer had only one motive, but we can imagine many motives, any one of which would have been sufficient to cause his literary adventure.
column3834: These may be indicated as the urge to chronicle, the urge to attract, the urge to worship, and the urge to create.
column3835: And all these are related to and possibly included by the need of self-expression.
column3836: Among the simplest and least literary people, events that greatly disturb the routine of life--wars, famines, pestilences, earthquakes--seem to develop writers automatically.
column3837: The great thing has happened and must have a record safer than man's fickle memory.
column3838: So inevitably come the chronicler and his chronicle.
column3840: But the desire to ensure remembrance of events is not in itself sufficient to ensure the existence of literature.
column3841: There is also what I have termed the urge to attract.
column3842: The savage warrior may carve on stone or paint upon a strip of pale bark a record of his own brave victory or ingenious escape.
column3843: This he does to attract the attention and admiration of his public, such as it is, to his courage and intelligence.
column3844: And also the mere making of the record is in itself an achievement certain to bring to its maker the wonder and esteem of those lacking this strange power.
column3845: And this sort of admiration, he finds, comes to him even when the things about which he writes are not his own doings.
column3846: So subjective art comes into existence.
column3847: Man writes because of the urge to worship to-day, as he has always done.
column3848: He utters prayers that have been provided for his needs by divinely constituted authorities, and to the unspoken ejaculation of his heart he silently gives the best literary form possible to him--the directness and passionate simplicity proper to great literature.
column3849: He repeats, when he prays in accordance with the forms prescribed by the Church, great literature which came into existence originally in response to the urge to worship.
column3850: And in all languages the writings of most enduring loveliness, even apart from those divinely inspired, are those which relate most closely to worship--those writings made immortal by the love of God.
column3851: So writers may fulfill the purpose for which they are made by writing--may know God better by writing about Him, increase their love of Him by expressing it in beautiful words, serve Him in this world by means of their best talent, and because of this service and His mercy be happy with Him forever in Heaven.
column3852: There is also the motive which perhaps gives rise to the common and fallacious idea of the writer's inspiration--the motive which I have designated as the urge to create.
column3853: Of course the only true creator is God, and for a creature to seem to create may be a perilous thing, savoring of blasphemy.
column3854: Certainly the evil egotism of some writers, using their talent for the destruction of their souls and those of others, is a blasphemous thing.
column3855: This is a matter better suited for discussion by a moral theologian than by a critic, but surely it is possible for the writer to assay his task of creating a work of art the more humbly and the more joyfully because it is done in reverent imitation of the Maker or Poet of the universe.
column3856: Now, a writer does not analyze or separate his motives.
column3857: They all are related to and possibly included by the need of self-expression.
column3858: There is an idea in the writer's brain which he wishes to put into words and on paper.
column3859: He does so, without bothering to try to discover why he has this impulse.
column3860: The existence of these motives, in various combinations, is evident in all literature.
column3861: The novelist wishes to create a thing of beauty, to chronicle certain actual or possible events, to attract admiration to himself and perhaps to a certain class or race of men.
column3862: If he is a great writer he has also, even if he be not thoroughly conscious of it, the desire to worship--he uses his talent honestly and skillfully, for God's sake, making an acceptable offering.
column3863: He may write a drama of modern life, a story of pioneer days in the Far West, a sonnet to a buttercup, a pamphlet in favor of improved tenement houses, a history of the Spanish-American War.
column3864: Whatever he may write, his desire is to chronicle, attract, and to create.
column3865: And if he be a great writer his desire also is to worship.
column3866: The power and desire to influence thought possessed by skillful writers has caused the world sometimes to regard them as actually the leaders of mankind's spiritual and intellectual endeavors.
column3867: Writers themselves are quick to take this point of view; we have in America hundreds of popular novelists who have no hesitation in advising humanity about all its moral problems, thousands of minor poets who will answer the questions of the ages in a sonnet or a handful of free verse.
column3868: There are some reasons for the writers to be justly considered leaders of popular thought.
column3869: As a class, they understand humanity, and sympathize with it.
column3870: They have the passions and hopes and loves of the rest of the world, intensified.
column3871: Also they have a sense of artistic, or, as it is called, poetic justice, and poetic justice usually is Christian justice.
column3872: But writers are unfitted to be leaders of popular thought by many disqualifications inseparable from their craft.
column3873: Interested as they are in the rest of humanity, they inevitably are set apart from it by reason of their exceptional gift.
column3874: They show their sense of this separation, even when they do not openly admit it, by dressing and talking and living in a manner different from that common to their fellow-citizens.
column3875: The velvet jacket, the long hair, the flowing necktie, the Bohemian studio, the defiance of custom and sometimes of law--these things are indications of that separation from mankind which makes the writer an unsafe leader of popular thought.
column3876: There is also the danger that the writer will, if he become a leader of thought, grow intoxicated with power, and lead thought irresponsibly, foolishly, wickedly, having in mind not the welfare of humanity but the delight of leadership.
column3877: To this temptation all leaders of thought--politicians, educators, investigators--are liable, but the writers most of all.
column3878: The proper function of the writer is rather to interpret than to lead the thought of his time.
column3879: Seldom does a writer actually give the world a new idea.
column3880: What he does is to give expression to an idea which has lain dormant in the mind of the people awaiting his revealing and quickening touch.
column3881: There is a hope or a fear in the minds of men--it finds expression in deeds and simultaneously in words.

column4199: LIONEL JOHNSON, ERNEST DOWSON, AUBREY BEARDSLEY In considering that brief and tumultuous period in English literature which is sometimes called The Æsthetic Renaissance, it is inevitable that three figures should stand out with particular vividness.

column4288: The real Ernest Dowson was not the picturesque vagabond about whom Mr. Blackie Murdoch has written, but the man who with all his heart praised "meekness and vigilance and chastity," who "was faithful" in his pathetic ineffective fashion, who knew at last the fidelity of his eternal Mother, who, in Katherine Brégy's beautiful words, "laid his broken body in consecrated ground and followed his bruised soul, with her pitiful asperging prayers."
column4289: In considering the eccentricities of "The Savoy" and "The Yellow Book," in considering all the literary and artistic artificialities of the eighteen-nineties, it seems to me that one real value of the cult of peacocks and green carnations, of artificial paganism and sophisticated loveliness, is that it furnishes a splendidly contrasting background for the white genius of Lionel Johnson.
column4290: This aristocratic and wealthy young Oxford graduate might so easily have become an æsthete and nothing more!
column4291: His environment, many of his friendships, even his discipleship, as it may be called, to Walter Pater might naturally be expected to cause him to develop into a mere dilettante, interested only in delicate and superficial beauty, having, by way of moral code, an earnest desire to live up to his blue chine.
column4293: He was a sound and accomplished scholar, writing Latin hymns that for their grace and authentic ecclesiastical style might stand beside those of Adam of St. Victor or of St. Bernard himself.
column4294: Nor was he less deft in his manipulation of the style of the classical authors, as many graceful lines show.
column4295: And this, remember, was at a time when Latin was most absolutely a dead language to most young English poets, whose attention was given entirely to the picturesque attractions of the Parisian _argot_ beloved of the decadents.
column4296: The æsthetic movement of the eighteen-nineties was merely a search for beauty--merely a revolt against Victorian agnosticism and materialism.
column4297: Johnson found the adventure which all the young poets and artists were seeking; he knew that the only answer to their question was the Catholic Faith.
column4298: The atmosphere of the literary world in which he lived seems to have had no effect upon Lionel Johnson's mind and soul.
column4299: He was "of the centre" not "of the movement."
column4300: He gladly accepted the gracious traditions of English poetry.
column4301: He followed the time-hallowed conventions of his craft as faithfully as did Tennyson.
column4302: He had no desire to toss Milton's wreath either to Whitman or to Baudelaire.
column4303: But these virtues are perhaps chiefly negative.
column4304: Almost the same thing might be said of many poets, of the late Stephen Phillips, for example, who certainly was an honest traditionalist, uninfluenced by decadence or æstheticism.
column4305: But Lionel Johnson had also (what Stephen Phillips lacked) a great and beautiful philosophy.
column4307: He was so fortunate as to hold the Catholic Faith.
column4308: This Faith inspired his best poems, shines through them and makes them, as the word is used, immortal.
column4309: While Lionel Johnson was not exclusively a devotional and religious poet, the theme which he sang with the most splendid passion and the most consummate art was the Catholic Church.
column4310: This was the great influence in his life; it is to this that his poetry owes most of its enduring beauty.
column4311: But there were other influences, there were other things which claimed, to a less degree, his devotion.
column4313: Lionel Johnson's chivalrous loyalty to Ireland was not without its quaint humor.
column4314: He was descended from the severe and brutal general who savagely put down the insurrection of 1798.
column4315: But he by no means shared his ancestor's views in Irish matters; he was an enthusiastic advocate of Irish freedom and a devoted lover of everything Irish.
column4316: Although he hailed with delight the revival of ancient Celtic customs and the ancient Celtic language, Lionel Johnson was far from being what we have come to call a neo-Celt.
column4317: He did not spend his time in writing elaborately annotated chants in praise of Cuchulain and Deidre and Oengus, and other creatures of legend; the attempt to reëstablish Ireland's ancient paganism seemed to him singularly unintelligent.
column4318: He saw that the greatest glory of Ireland is her fidelity to the Catholic Faith, a fidelity which countless cruel persecutions have only strengthened.
column4319: And so when he wrote of Ireland's dead, he did not see them entering into some Ossianic land of dead warriors.
column4320: Instead he wrote:   For their loyal love, nought less,     Than the stress of death sufficed:   Now with Christ, in blessedness,     Triumph they, imparadised.
column4321: Similarly, in what is generally considered to be his greatest poem, the majestic and passionate "Ireland," his most joyous vision is that of the "Bright souls of Saints, glad choirs of intercession from the Gael," and he concludes with this splendid prayer:   O Rose!
column4328: Pity, and turn they face,     Praying thy Son, even as we pray thee now,   For thy dear sake to set thine Ireland free:     Pray thou thy Little Child!
column4330: who can help her, but in mercy He?
column4331: Pray then, pray thou for Ireland, Mother mild!
column4333: Pray the Sacred Heart:   His, at Whose word depart     Sorrows and hates, home to Hell's waste and wild.
column4334: Lionel Johnson was, as Miss Louise Imogen Guiney has written, "a tower of wholesomeness in the decadence which his short life spanned."
column4335: His purely secular poems are best when his Catholic Faith, seemingly without his willing it, unexpectedly shines out in a splendor of radiant phrases.
column4336: And of all his poems, those which constitute his most important contributions to literature, are those which are directly the fruit of his religious experiences or of his love for Ireland.
column4337: He was not so great a poet as Francis Thompson.
column4338: He never wrote a poem that will stand comparison with "The Hound of Heaven" or the "Orient Ode."
column4339: But the sum of the beauty in all his work is great, and his poetry is, on the whole, more companionable than that of Francis Thompson; it is more human, more personal, more intimate.
column4340: And to at least two of Lionel Johnson's poems, the adjective "great" may, by every sound critical standard, safely be applied.
column4341: One of these is the "Dark Angel," a masterly study of the psychology of temptation, written in stanzas that glow with feeling, that are the direct and passionate utterance of the poet's soul, and yet are as polished and accurate as if their author's only purpose had been to make a thing of beauty.
column4342: The other is "Te Martyrum Candidatus," a poem which may without question be given its place in any anthology which contains "Burning Babe," "The Kings," and Crashaw's "Hymn to St.
column4344: It has seemed to me that these brave and beautiful lines, which have for their inspiration the love of God, and echo with their chiming syllables the hoof-beats of horses bearing knights to God's battles, might serve as a fitting epitaph for the accomplished scholar, the true poet, the noble and kindly Catholic gentleman who wrote them.
column4345: SWINBURNE AND FRANCIS THOMPSON I feel a certain diffidence in approaching the subject of Francis Thompson before such an audience as this.
column4346: For I know that there are many among you who could teach me much about that great poet, the modern laureate of the Catholic Church.
column4347: I suppose that many of you have studied the profound philosophy of "From the Night of Forebeing," "The Mistress of Vision" and "The Hound of Heaven," have curiously examined the beautiful verbal intricacies of "Sister Songs" and "The Orient Ode," and are familiar with the triumphs and the tragedies of Francis Thompson's brief life.
column4348: But there may be some among you to whom Francis Thompson is little more than a name.
column4349: To such let me say that Francis Thompson was born of Catholic parents in Lancashire, England, in 1859, that he died, fortified by the last rites of the Church he loved, at the age of forty-eight, that most of his life was spent in poverty and ill-health, that he was subject to terrible and persistent temptations, but remained faithful to the Church, and made in the Church's honor some of the greatest poems in the English language.
column4350: I compare him to a contemporary poet, Algernon Charles Swinburne, chiefly because Swinburne was the poet of Paganism as Francis Thompson was the poet of Catholicity, because their careers present interesting resemblances as well as interesting contrasts, and because both are what is called "Victorian" poets.
column4351: Now, in this connection let me ask you if you ever seriously considered the advantages of living in a Republic, of living, for example, in the United States of America instead of in England?
column4352: There is, for example, the recurrent excitement of changing the president once every four years, of having every so often a new chief executive on whom to vent your enthusiastic affection or your enthusiastic loathing.
column4353: A president is a wonderful safety-valve for the pent-up feelings of a nation.
column4354: The suffrage, the right to vote, must be a golden privilege indeed, otherwise so many members of the wiser sex would not pursue it with such zeal and devotion.
column4355: But the advantage of living in a Republic to which I desire particularly to call your attention this afternoon is the advantage of escaping from the custom of calling periods of artistic and literary endeavor after the sovereigns who happened to rule during them.
column4356: You never hear James Whitcomb Riley or Edwin Markham spoken of as Wilsonian poets.
column4357: But you do hear Ben Jonson called an Elizabethan poet, which is just as absurd.
column4358: You never hear Bryant and Whittier called poets of the Lincoln period.
column4359: But you do hear such utterly dissimilar poets as Algernon Charles Swinburne and Francis Thompson spoken of as Victorian poets.
column4362: Why should the age that glowed with the deathless flames of Shakespeare's genius, that echoed with Ben Jonson's lyric laughter, that was pierced by the poignant music of Robert Southwell, the martyred Jesuit poet, be named after Elizabeth, the persecutor of the saints, the vain and selfish and cruel woman who then occupied England's throne, to England's lasting shame?
column4363: And why are we to-day considering, in Swinburne and Francis Thompson, two Victorian poets?
column4365: Of course, Queen Victoria was a good wife and mother, a noble gentlewoman.
column4366: I think that we all like everything that we know about Queen Victoria except perhaps her politics.
column4367: But why should the name of this estimable woman be used to designate the intellectual and spiritual life of the time during which she ruled, a life from which she was as remote as was the Queen of Sheba?
column4368: Why should we give the placid name Victorian to that time of violent sin and violent virtue, of passionate infidelity and passionate faith, that time which produced the Darwinian theory, and the Oxford Movement, which produced the cruel reign of dogmatic science and the Catholic renascence, which produced the poetry of Algernon Charles Swinburne and the poetry of Francis Thompson?
column4369: The combination of these two names may strike you as unusual.
column4370: You know that Swinburne was what is called a Pagan, that he hated all forms of Christianity and especially the Catholic Church.
column4371: You know also that Francis Thompson was the Church's poet-laureate, the greatest Catholic poet of modern times.
column4372: And you wonder why Swinburne and Francis Thompson should be mentioned in the same breath.
column4373: Well, great as are the differences between these poets, the resemblances are striking.
column4374: It is true that when Swinburne was at the height of his fame, Francis Thompson was running errands and holding horses in the London streets, his genius practically unknown.
column4375: Yet he was famous before Swinburne's death, and there are other points of contact beside that of time between this militant pagan and this militant Christian.
column4376: In the first place, both were poets.
column4377: Both had genuine talent, and both had a strong desire to do the work of the poet, that is, to find beauty and to bind beauty with a chain of linked rhyme.
column4378: Now the poet's search for beauty often is difficult, and it was especially difficult in London in the latter days of the nineteenth century.
column4379: All the poets were seeking for beauty, but the scientists had been industriously trying to drive beauty out of the world.
column4380: Of course, they had not succeeded, any more than the French Atheist succeeded a few years ago in carrying out his blasphemous threat of putting out that light in the heavens.
column4381: But they had thrown a veil over the face of beauty, and made beauty hard to see except for those who looked with the strong eyes of faith.
column4384: Browning thought that beauty was in humanity.
